stem: A 54-year-old woman who recently received a renal transplant comes to the emergency department due to fevers and malaise for the past 24 hours. She also has had a cough productive of yellow sputum over the past 2 days. No one around her has similar symptoms. Three weeks ago, the patient underwent cadaveric renal transplant for long-standing renal disease. Her immediate postsurgical course was uneventful, and she was extubated 3 days after surgery. Her other medical problems include gastroesophageal reflux, hyperlipidemia, and eczema. After the transplantation, she moved in with her sister, who had just donated her 2 cats to a local pet store. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Her current medications include prednisone, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, valganciclovir, sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim, pravastatin, and omeprazole. She has no known drug allergies. Her temperature is 38.5 C (101.3 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 18/min. Pulse oximetry shows oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Breath sounds are decreased in the left lung base with mild wheezing over the upper lung fields bilaterally. Her abdomen is soft and nontender without a palpable spleen tip. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 10.4 g/dL Hematocrit 32% Platelets 187,000/mm3 Leukocytes 15,600/mm3 Serum chemistry Sodium 140 mEq/L Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Chloride 90 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 17 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Calcium 9.1 mg/dL Glucose 96 mg/dL Chest-x ray reveals a left lower lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
explanation: This patient's presentation is concerning for nosocomial pneumonia following recent hospitalization for cadaveric renal transplant. The table summarizes common infections seen in solid organ transplant patients based on the amount of time elapsed following surgery. Within the early posttransplant period (<1 month), patients are at risk for nosocomial infections due to prolonged hospitalization and multiple catheter and device placements/instrumentations. Transplant patients requiring mechanical ventilation are particularly susceptible to nosocomial infections due to gram-positive organisms (eg, vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), gram-negative organisms (eg, Legionella, Pseudomonas), fungi (eg, Candida species), and Clostridium difficile colitis. Pseudomonas commonly colonizes hospital equipment (eg, mechanical ventilation) and is the most likely cause of this patient's pneumonia. (Choice A) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections usually occur between 1-6 months after transplantation and would be unlikely in this patient taking valganciclovir, which is effective for CMV prophylaxis. (Choice B) Opportunistic infection (OI) with Nocardia is rare in the early posttransplant period; it tends to occur >6 months following transplantation, likely reflecting the impact of immunosuppression duration on Ol development. (Choice C) Pasteurella multocida is usually found in the normal respiratory flora of domestic pets (eg. dogs, cats). Human infection (eg, cellulitis, respiratory infections, or bone/joint disease) is typically due to animal bites or scratches. This patient's sister donated her cats, and there is no history of animal bites to suggest Pasteurella infection. (Choice D) Pneumocystis jirovecii usually causes pulmonary complications in transplant patients 3-4 months after surgery. In addition, this patient is on sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim for P jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis. Educational objective: Solid organ transplant patients are more susceptible to nosocomial infections within a month of surgery due to prolonged hospitalization, mechanical ventilation, immunosuppression, and exposure to multiple catheters or devices. Common organisms causing nosocomial pneumonia in transplant patients include vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, Candida, and Pseudomonas.

stem: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. She began feeling unwell 6 days ago with fever, throbbing pain behind the eyes, diffuse myalgias, and abdominal pain. Her fever improved 2 days ago, but she noticed an erythematous skin rash developing on her trunk and upper and lower extremities. A few hours prior to admission, the patient had an episode of epistaxis and a syncopal episode when cleaning the bathroom. She has no other medical problems. She returned from a trip to southern Mexico 10 days ago and states that one of her travel companions also has had fevers and myalgias. The patient received the typhoid vaccine before her trip. Her temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 86/60 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination shows mild abdominal tenderness with no hepatosplenomegaly. Examination of the hands is shown below. Laboratory studies are as follows: Hematocrit 52% Platelets 90,000/mm3 Leukocytes 3,300/mm3 Serum sodium 141 mEq/L Serum potassium 4.1 mEq/L Serum creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Dengue fever (DF) is a common cause of fever in travelers returning from the Caribbean, parts of Asia, and South America. In addition to fever, the first period of illness (usually 3-5 days) is marked by myalgias, retro-orbital pain/headache, and bleeding complications (eg, epistaxis). As these symptoms improve, a characteristic macular or maculopapular rash ("islands of white in a sea of red") may appear. At around the same time, patients enter the critical phase of the illness; some may develop capillary leakage with edema, effusions, hypotension/shock, and severe hemorrhage. A positive tourniquet test may be seen (petechiae following sphygmomanometer inflation for 5 minutes over the arm). Laboratory abnormalities include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and an elevated hematocrit due to hemoconcentration (even in the absence of hemorrhage). Diagnosis is made via serology or direct testing for viral components, and care is largely supportive. (Choice B) Epstein-Barr virus can cause infectious mononucleosis, which typically presents with pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and lymphocytosis. (Choice C) Leptospirosis may present similarly to DF. However, patients usually have conjunctival suffusion, pulmonary involvement (eg, cough, dyspnea), and/or renal involvement (eg. proteinuria, electrolyte abnormalities). (Choice D) Secondary syphilis can present with systemic symptoms and a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. However, it is not usually associated with bleeding diathesis, hypotension, or thrombocytopenia. (Choice E) Typhoid fever typically presents with weeks of sequential fever followed by rose spots (faint salmon-colored macules on trunk and abdomen) and abdominal pain; some cases may progress to hepatosplenomegaly, bleeding, and shock. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with DF. In addition, she received the typhoid vaccine before the trip. Educational objective: Dengue fever is a common cause of fever in travelers returning from an endemic area (eg, Caribbean, parts of Asia, and South America). Patients typically develop fever, retro-orbital pain/headache, a characteristic macular rash, and bleeding complications. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are common laboratory abnormalities.

stem: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband due to fever and confusion. He notes that the patient began having fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting yesterday. She was also disoriented and made many odd statements to her children. The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease and underwent simultaneous pancreas-kidney transplantation 2 years ago. She takes maintenance immunosuppressive therapy. Temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 21/min. The patient is lethargic and ill-appearing. No skin rash is present. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and there are no heart murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The patient is oriented only to self and moves all extremities to pain. No nuchal rigidity or signs of meningismus are elicited. Leukocyte count is 15,500/mm3, serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL, and plasma glucose is 90 mg/dL Blood cultures are obtained, and empiric antibiotics are administered. CT scan of the head shows no hemorrhage or mass, and lumbar puncture is subsequently performed. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results are as follows: Glucose 30 mg/dL Protein 120 mg/dL Leukocytes 1,000/mm3 with 80% neutrophils CSF Gram stain reveals numerous gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following is the best treatment?
explanation: This patient with fever, headache, and altered mental status has 3 of the 4 classic manifestations of acute bacterial meningitis. All 4 manifestations (including neck stiffness) are present in <45% of cases. Priorities of care include the pursuit of a microbial diagnosis by blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Gram stain/culture and prompt initiation of empiric antimicrobial treatment to limit risk of neurologic sequelae and death. CSF Gram stain has a sensitivity of 60%-90% and a specificity of >97% when lumbar puncture is performed prior to antibiotic therapy. Patients who receive antibiotics prior to lumbar puncture may have lower yields. Positive Gram stain (or culture) should prompt the transition from empiric to targeted antibiotic therapy. This patient has gram-positive bacilli in the CSF, indicating likely Listeria monocytogenes meningoencephalitis, which most commonly affects neonates, adults age >50, and those with immunocompromise (eg, immunosuppressive treatment). Empiric therapy should now be narrowed to intravenous ampicillin or penicillin G. An aminoglycoside is sometimes added for synergy. (Choice B) Cefepime monotherapy is primarily used to treat bacterial meningitis when CSF Gram stain shows gram-negative (not gram-positive) bacilli, and patients are at risk for resistant organisms (eg, Pseudomonas, Acinetobacter) due to immunocompromise, a neurosurgical device, or recent neurosurgery or head trauma. (Choices C, D, and E) Vancomycin is primarily used in the treatment of bacterial meningitis to cover for cephalosporin-resistant strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae (gram-positive cocci) or when Staphylococcus aureus or coagulase-negative staphylococcus is likely (eg, recent head trauma, neurosurgery, neurosurgical device). It is also used in combination with cefepime and ampicillin to empirically treat bacterial meningitis when patients are immunocompromised. Listeria is almost universally sensitive to ampicillin and penicillin G; vancomycin is not required at this time. Educational objective: Patients with suspected bacterial meningitis who have a positive cerebrospinal fluid Gram stain should have empiric therapy narrowed to target the likely organism. Patients with gram-positive bacilli are likely to have Listeria monocytogenes meningoencephalitis; first-line treatment consists of ampicillin or penicillin G with or without a synergistic aminoglycoside.

stem: A 28-year-old woman with fever and lethargy is brought to the emergency department accompanied by her roommate. The roommate reports that the patient appeared well last night but awoke this morning confused. Throughout the morning she became increasingly confused and eventually unarousable, prompting her roommate to call an ambulance. Her past medical history is significant for idiopathic thrombocytopenia purpura. There is no history of recent travel. Her temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 84/42 mm Hg, pulse is 122/min, and respirations are 28/min. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing woman. Pupils are equal and round but sluggish. Lungs have patchy rales. Abdominal examination reveals a surgical scar in the left upper quadrant. There are diffuse ecchymotic areas throughout the torso and lower extremities, with areas of bullae and vesicle formation. There is no rash on the palms or soles. There are no meningeal signs. Laboratory results as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 16.2 g/dL Hematocrit 54% Platelets 40,000/μL Leukocytes 19,800/μL Neutrophils 58% Band forms 32% Lymphocytes 7% Monocytes 2% Serum chemistry Sodium 126 mEq/L Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Chloride 94 mEq/L Bicarbonate 11 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 62 mg/dL Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL Serum creatine kinase 7990 U/L Chest x-ray reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following antibiotics would be most effective at targeting the suspected pathogen?
explanation: This patient has fever, hypotension, altered mental status, and rash (very likely purpura fulminans). She likely has a history of splenectomy (left upper quadrant surgical scar), which increases her risk for an encapsulated organism (eg, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Haemophilus influenzae). Her presentation and rapid deterioration with severe sepsis and DIC make meningococcemia from N meningitidis the most likely diagnosis. N meningitidis is the second most common cause of adult bacterial meningitis in the world and is transmitted via the respiratory route through pharyngeal secretions. Patients may present with fever, severe myalgias (often misdiagnosed early as viral influenza), or severe sepsis without focal signs of meningitis (summarized in the table). Nearly 25% of patients may present with purpura fulminans due to circulating bacterial endotoxin causing cutaneous hemorrhage, progressive skin and soft-tissue necrosis, and subsequent DIC. Early empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, aggressive fluids, oxygen, and vasopressor support should be initiated immediately. Third-generation cephalosporins (eg. ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) are the most appropriate therapy for N meningitidis, but vancomycin is also added to cover for possible pneumococcal infection until final culture results are available. (Choice A) Ampicillin is effective for suspected Listeria meningitis, which is seen more commonly in neonates, adults age 50, and immunocompromised patients. (Choice C) Clindamycin is used to treat streptococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS), which usually presents with extremity or soft-tissue pain followed by ecchymoses, skin sloughing, and necrotizing myositis/fascitis. Although TSS can present with fever and altered mental status, it does not usually have the petechial rash seen in this patient. Clindamycin also does not have activity against Neisseria species. (Choice D) Doxycycline is used to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, in which rash usually does not appear until the third to fifth day after onset of fever. The rash starts around the ankles and wrists, involves the palms and soles, and is usually petechial. This patient's rash started abruptly along with the fever, has evolved into bullae, and is not present on the palms and soles. (Choice E) Vancomycin is added to a third-generation cephalosporin for the treatment of bacterial meningitis to include coverage for possible penicillin-resistant pneumococcus. However, it is not effective against N meningitidis and should not be used as monotherapy. Educational objective: Patients with history of splenectomy are susceptible to severe infections from encapsulated bacteria (eg, N meningitidis). Meningococcemia may present with fever, myalgias, purpura fulminans, meningitis, DIC, and shock (with or without adrenal insufficiency). Treatment includes third-generation cephalosporins (eg. ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) and vancomycin. Close respiratory contacts of affected individuals require prophylaxis with rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone.

stem: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and decreased level of consciousness. She is accompanied by her boyfriend. The patient became increasingly confused throughout the morning and eventually unarousable, prompting him to call an ambulance. After initial evaluation, lumbar puncture is performed and empiric antibiotic therapy is started. Cerebral spinal fluid shows Gram-negative diplococci. She is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following individuals needs antibiotics for post-exposure prophylaxis?
choice_a: Medical resident who performed the initial lumbar puncture
choice_b: Emergency department nurse who triaged the patient
choice_c: Patient's boyfriend, who received the meningococcal vaccine 1 year ago
choice_d: Transporter who took the patient from the emergency department to the intensive care unit
explanation: This patient's presentation of fever, rash, decreased level of consciousness and Gram-negative diplococci on lumbar puncture suggests likely meningococcal infection from Neisseria meningitidis. Meningococcus usually spreads through droplets of respiratory secretions and can transmit rapidly to contacts within close proximity (3-6 feet). Individuals require antibiotic prophylaxis if they have close contact and prolonged duration (8 hours) regardless of vaccination status. Healthcare workers (with close proximity and prolonged duration or exposure to respiratory secretions) and close contacts of infected patients with meningococcal disease ideally should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis within the first 24 hours of the patient's diagnosis. Exposure usually occurs during the week prior to onset of symptoms or 24 hours prior to antimicrobial therapy. Recommended regimens include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone. This patient's boyfriend would warrant antimicrobial therapy. (Choices A, B, and D) The nurse, medical resident, and transporter would need antibiotic prophylaxis only if they were exposed to respiratory secretions or were in very close proximity to the secretions for a prolonged period. These workers had a relatively short duration of exposure and would benefit less from antibiotic prophylaxis. If this patient required intubation, the physician who performed it would require antimicrobial prophylaxis. Educational objective: Regardless of vaccination status, healthcare workers (with close proximity and prolonged duration or exposure to respiratory secretions) and close contacts of infected patients with meningococcal disease should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis, ideally within the first 24 hours of patient diagnosis. Recommended regimens include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone.

stem: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after waking with new left-sided facial weakness. She has also had headaches over the last 10 days that are throbbing, 4 of 10 in intensity, located "all over" her head, and associated with photophobia but no nausea. She has had no double vision, limb weakness, numbness, difficulty swallowing, or recent head trauma, but she does note some malaise and mild neck stiffness. The patient has a history of migraines but says her current headaches are different in quality and more persistent. She has seasonal allergies and takes over-the-counter antihistamines as needed. She traveled to India 4 months ago and is currently living with her grandparents in Connecticut for the summer. She is single and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min and regular, and respirations are 15/min. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Mucous membranes are dry. Neurologic examination shows slight nuchal rigidity and photophobia. Cranial nerve testing reveals a decreased corneal reflex on the left as well as upper and lower left-sided facial weakness. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely complication if this patient's condition is left untreated?
explanation: This patient who currently resides in Connecticut has evidence of facial nerve palsy (unilateral facial weakness, impaired corneal reflex) and likely meningitis (headache, photophobia, nuchal rigidity), raising suspicion for early disseminated Lyme disease. Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness endemic to the northeastern United States. Manifestations typically arise in 3 progressive clinical stages: Early localized disease - A few weeks of viral-like symptoms and a spreading, annular rash (erythema migrans). Early disseminated disease - Several weeks or months later, patients can develop acute arthralgias, carditis (eg, atrioventricular block), and neurologic disease (eg, facial nerve palsy, meningitis). Late Lyme disease - Late symptoms usually occur months or years after the initial inoculation. The most common manifestation is intermittent or persistent arthritis in ≥1 large joints (particularly the knee). More serious neurologic disease such as Lyme encephalopathy can also occur. Although Lyme disease usually progresses in a stepwise fashion, there can occasionally be manifestations of multiple stages at the same time. Patients can also have symptoms of early disseminated or late Lyme disease without having manifestations of previous stages. (Choice B) Lyme carditis generally occurs within a few months of infection and is considered a manifestation of early disseminated Lyme disease. The most common finding is atrioventricular conduction block, but patients can also occasionally develop myopericarditis. Chronic dilated cardiomyopathy is rare. (Choice C) Lower extremity paraplegia and meningitis can be seen with tuberculosis infections of the central nervous system. Although this patient did travel to a TB-endemic country (India), central nervous system tuberculosis is much less common than Lyme disease and rarely causes facial nerve palsy. (Choice D) Seizures are more common with encephalitis (eg, herpes encephalitis) than with meningitis. Lyme disease is not typically associated with an increased risk of seizures. (Choice E) Conjunctivitis is seen in approximately 10% of cases of early disseminated Lyme disease. Other ocular manifestations are rare. Late Lyme disease is most likely to cause arthritis, not vision loss. Educational objective: The manifestations of Lyme disease are typically categorized into 3 progressive stages. Early localized infection is marked by a viral-like syndrome and erythema migrans. Weeks or months later, patients can develop signs of early disseminated disease such as arthralgias, carditis (eg, atrioventricular block), and nervous system abnormalities (eg, facial nerve palsy, meningitis). Late Lyme disease is typically associated with intermittent or persistent arthritis in ≥1 large joints (particularly the knee).

stem: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department in January due to fever and shortness of breath. A week ago, he developed fever, malaise, muscle aches, and rhinorrhea. The symptoms largely resolved 2 days ago, but this morning the patient began having productive cough of green-yellow sputum, shortness of breath, and pleuritic chest pain. He has had no recent travel or other significant illness. The patient has not received the influenza vaccine. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and takes insulin. Temperature is 39.1 C (102.4 F), blood pressure is 135/67 mm Hg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry shows 90% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing and in mild respiratory distress. He coughs frequently during the examination. Lung examination shows bronchial breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lung field. Leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3 with 82% neutrophils. Chest x-ray shows a dense right lower-lobe consolidation with a small area of lucency and small right-sided pleural effusion. Rapid influenza test is positive. Which of the following empiric treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
explanation: This young patient had influenza symptoms, transiently improved, and then developed worsened fever and lower respiratory manifestations (productive cough, pleurisy, dyspnea), raising strong suspicion for influenza complicated by secondary bacterial pneumonia. Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus are the leading pathogens; Haemophilus influenzae is sometimes isolated. Most cases occur in patients age >65 or those with certain underlying conditions. Young, previously healthy patients can also be affected; these cases are often linked to community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The empiric treatment of post-influenza pneumonia should include: Typical community-acquired pneumonia coverage (eg, ceftriaxone and azithromycin) MRSA coverage (eg, vancomycin) Antiviral treatment (eg, oseltamivir) - patients who develop influenza complications such as secondary pneumonia are typically treated with antivirals even if they present >48 hours after influenza symptom onset. (Choice A) Primary tuberculosis typically presents with the gradual onset of fever and pleuritic chest pain, sometimes with fatigue, cough, or arthralgias. Chest x-ray usually shows hilar adenopathy without the dense consolidation seen in this patient. (Choice B) Community-acquired MRSA is a common cause of secondary bacterial pneumonia following influenza infection and must be covered empirically with vancomycin. If cultures or Gram stain reveal that MRSA is unlikely, vancomycin can be discontinued. (Choice C) Piperacillin/tazobactam is typically added for anti-pseudomonal coverage in hospital-acquired pneumonia. This patient has no risk factors for pseudomonal pneumonia (eg, prior hospitalization, immunocompromised status, cirrhosis, recent antibiotic or glucocorticoid use) and should receive vancomycin plus community-acquired pneumonia treatment. (Choice E) Patients with uncomplicated influenza who have had >48 hours of symptoms are generally managed with supportive care. Supportive care would be insufficient for this patient with pneumonia (fever, productive cough, leukocytosis, pulmonary infiltrate). Educational objective: Secondary bacterial pneumonia is typically characterized by a transient improvement of influenza symptoms followed by worsened fever and lower respiratory tract illness. Most cases are caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, but methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is also a frequent culprit, particularly in young, previously healthy patients. Empiric treatment should include coverage for community-acquired pneumonia (eg, ceftriaxone and azithromycin) and for MRSA (eg, vancomycin).

stem: A 41-year-old man with known HIV infection comes to the emergency department with crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea over the last 3-4 weeks. He has no vomiting or black or bloody stools. However, he has lost a few pounds due to poor appetite. The patient has had HIV infection, acquired through intravenous drug use, for the past 9 years. He has refused to take highly active antiretroviral therapy, and his medical follow-up has been poor. Six months ago, he was seen in an urgent care clinic for thrush and was prescribed oral fluconazole. His temperature is 38.1° C (100.7° F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry shows 95% on room air. The patient's body mass index is 17 kg/m2. On physical examination, he has poor oral dentition. There are no skin rashes or lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is diffusely tender, but there is no guarding or rebound tenderness. The liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the costal margin. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 8.6 g/dL Platelets 65,000/µL Leukocytes 2,800/µL Neutrophils 60% Lymphocytes 30% Serum chemistry Blood urea nitrogen 6 mg/dL Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL Liver function studies Total protein 6.5 g/dL Albumin 1.9 g/dL Total bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 370 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 237 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 324 U/L Blood, plasma, and serum Lactate dehydrogenase, serum 172 U/L Lactic acid, venous blood 2.8 mg/dL Computed tomography scan of the abdomen shows thickening of the small bowel, mildly enlarged intra-abdominal and para-aortic lymph nodes, and hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
explanation: This patient's clinical presentation suggests atypical mycobacterial infection such as Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). MAC organisms (M avium or M intracellulare) are ubiquitous in the environment. Infection occurs via inhalation or ingestion before disseminating through lymphatics to cause bacteremia. The risk of conversion from colonization to MAC bacteremia in a patient with AIDS and a CD4+ of < 50 cells/µl is estimated to be 60% within 1 year. Prophylaxis includes weekly azithromycin or daily clarithromycin/rifabutin, which is continued until 3 months after CD4 > 100 cells/mm3. Localized MAC infection occurs in immunocompetent individuals or HIV patients on antiretroviral therapy (ART) as part of immune reconstitution. Patients may present with fever, leukocytosis, and focal lymphadenitis (cervical, intra-abdominal, mediastinal). Blood cultures are usually negative and diagnosis is confirmed with culture from lymph node aspirate. Disseminated MAC usually presents with fever, night sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss (wasting syndrome). Laboratory findings include anemia, pancytopenia (if bone marrow is involved), and elevated alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase. Diagnosis is confirmed by blood cultures, which may take up to 3 weeks to become positive. Bone marrow biopsy with acid-fast bacilli staining is more invasive but can isolate the mycobacteria. Computed tomography scans are nonspecific and can be normal or reveal lymphadenopathy, small bowel thickening, or hepatosplenomegaly. Treatment involves clarithromycin (preferred over azithromycin) and ethambutol. Rifabutin is added for patients with high mycobacterial loads (> 2 log colony-forming units/mL of blood) or ineffective ART. Patients already taking ART can continue the retroviral medications. Patients not taking ART usually start after 2 weeks of MAC treatment to decrease the chance of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome. (Choice B) Crohn's disease can present with prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. However, this patient's hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and low CD4 count are more suggestive of disseminated MAC infection. (Choice C) Cryptosporidiosis in HIV patients usually presents with secretory diarrhea, systemic symptoms and impaired vitamin B12 absorption. Biliary tract disease occurs in 10%-30% of HIV patients and presents with acalculous cholecystitis, sclerosing cholangitis, and pancreatitis. However, hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal lymphadenopathy are uncommon. (Choice D) Cytomegalovirus infection in HIV patients usually results in retinitis, painful esophagitis, and colitis. Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy in HIV patients usually indicate MAC infection, histoplasmosis, or lymphoma, but not cytomegalovirus infection. (Choice E) Acute hepatitis B viral infection typically presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant discomfort, and arthralgias with or without jaundice. Serum aminotransferase (ALT > AST) levels are usually > 1000 IU/L in the acute phase. Educational objective: Mycobacterium avium complex infection occurs in HIV-infected patients with CD4 < 50 cells/mm3. Disseminated disease presents with fever, night sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal lymphadenopathy are common. Diagnosis is made via blood cultures, and treatment includes clarithromycin and ethambutol.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever, malaise, headache, and myalgia. He has also noticed a nonpruritic skin rash on his right leg. The patient has had no abdominal pain, vomiting, or diarrhea. Prior medical problems include hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He is an ex-smoker and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient lives in Texas and a week ago returned from visiting family in Connecticut, where he spent most of his time outdoors. Temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 20/min. Examination shows no scleral icterus or lymphadenopathy. Breath sounds are mildly decreased throughout. The abdomen is soft with no hepatosplenomegaly. There is no neck stiffness. A 4-cm, erythematous skin rash with central clearing is present on the right popliteal area. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL Platelets 80,000/mm3 Leukocytes 2,800/mm3 Liver function studies Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 103 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 124 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 142 U/L Chest x-ray reveals no parenchymal opacity or pleural effusion. Which of the following diagnostic studies is most appropriate for this patient?
explanation: This patient who recently visited Connecticut developed influenza-like symptoms and erythema migrans (rash with central clearing) raising strong suspicion for early localized Lyme disease. However, the presence of high fever and cytopenias is atypical for Lyme disease and suggests coinfection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA). Both Lyme disease and HGA are transmitted by the Ixodes scapularis tick, and coinfection occurs in approximately 2%-15% of cases. HGA is characterized by influenza-like symptoms, high fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated aminotransferases. Rash is fairly uncommon and usually suggests coinfection with Lyme disease (erythema migrans) or a rickettsial organism. Diagnosis is made by serology (sensitive but must be measured during the acute and convalescent phases) or buffy coat or peripheral blood smear examination for characteristic intraleukocytic morulae (less sensitive but rapid). Empiric treatment with doxycycline should be initiated to prevent complications such as seizures, coma, and respiratory/renal failure. The I scapularis tick is also the vector for babesiosis, which is typically characterized by anemia (hemolytic) and thrombocytopenia and most commonly occurs in patients with a history of splenectomy. (Choice A) Parvovirus can cause flu-like symptoms, arthralgias, and/or erythema infectiosum, which is associated with a "slapped cheek" malar rash. Anemia is often a primary feature; leukopenia and thrombocytopenia occur less commonly. (Choice B) Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) serology is typically negative for the first several days of infection and is unhelpful in medical decision-making (as treatment with doxycycline should be initiated ≤5 days after symptom onset). In addition, the RMSF rash is typically petechial, starts on the ankles and wrists, and spreads centripetally (and to the palms and soles). (Choice C) Although this patient has leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, the presence of concurrent flulike symptoms, high fever, and erythema migrans likely indicates a tick-borne illness. Bone marrow biopsy is not needed at this time. (Choice D) This patient's erythema migrans and flulike symptoms suggest early localized Lyme disease; serology is most often negative at this stage and is not recommended (as early localized Lyme disease is a clinical diagnosis). Educational objective: Human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), a tick-borne illness, should be suspected in patients from endemic areas who develop flulike symptoms with leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia. Coinfection with Lyme disease occurs in up to 15% of cases (both are transmitted by the Ixodes scapularis tick) and should be suspected when patients also have a rash with central clearing. Diagnosis can be made with buffy coat or peripheral blood smear examination (intraleukocytic morulae); empiric treatment with doxycycline should be initiated while awaiting testing results.

stem: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 2-day history of generalized weakness, lightheadedness, palpitations, and poor energy. Four weeks ago, he noticed an annular rash on his right thigh that lasted for a couple of days and then faded. He has no fever, weight loss, chest pain, or headache. He lives on Long Island, New York, and jogs 7 miles 3 times a week. Which of the following is the most likely cardiac finding in this patient?
explanation: This patient is from a Lyme disease-endemic area and had a transient thigh rash 4 weeks earlier, suggesting Lyme disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Patients typically present with initial erythema migrans and nonspecific flu-like symptoms (eg, fever, fatigue, headache, and body aches). As the disease disseminates in the following weeks to months, patients may present with acute neurologic and/or cardiac symptoms as the first clinical sign of the disease. Lyme carditis, as in this patient, may be asymptomatic or present with palpitations (most common), lightheadedness, syncope, dyspnea, or chest pain. Palpitations can be a nonspecific finding and may not represent true underlying heart disease. Lyme carditis most commonly presents (objectively) with atrioventricular (AV) conduction blocks that sometimes fluctuate between first- and second-degree block. Progression to complete heart block is possible, and the risk is increased with PR interval > 300 msec. Lyme myopericarditis is usually self-limited and sometimes causes mild pericardial effusion but rarely causes cardiomegaly (Choices C and D). Although cardiomyopathy has been reported in Europe, there have been no such cases reported in the United States. Atrial and ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur less commonly in Lyme carditis (Choices A and E). Diagnosis is confirmed by clinical features and positive ELISA and western blot Lyme serologies. Current guidelines recommend hospital admission with IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone preferred) to prevent long-term complications in symptomatic patients and those with second- or third-degree AV block or first-degree AV block with PR interval > 300 msec. Oral antibiotics (eg, doxycycline, amoxicillin, and cefuroxime) should be continued at discharge for a 21- to 28-day total course. Complete AV block requires temporary pacing as these blocks are self-limited and usually improve within 1 week. Lesser conduction disturbances may take up to 6 weeks for resolution. Educational objective: Lyme carditis can be asymptomatic or present with palpitations, lightheadedness, syncope, dyspnea, or chest pain. Atrioventricular conduction block is the most common cardiac presentation and can progress to complete heart block. Hospital admission with IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone preferred) is recommended for symptomatic patients and those with second- or third-degree AV block or first-degree AV block with PR interval > 300 msec.

stem: A 62-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease comes to the emergency department with 2 days of fever and fatigue. Over the last 24 hours, he has developed progressive fatigue and confusion. The patient's past medical history is notable for a coronary catheterization 2 weeks ago with placement of an intracoronary stent in the right posterior descending artery. He was discharged home within 24 hours. He has no other medical history or prior surgeries. The patient lives in New York with his wife, who has been well. He has no recent travel and currently works as an accountant. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable but is clinically stable. His temperature is 38.6 C (101.5 F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 114/min and regular. There is no lymph node enlargement. There is no tenderness to palpation over the sinuses. The lungs are clear on auscultation. No heart murmurs are appreciated. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The tip of the spleen is not palpated. There is no rash. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL Hematocrit 34% Platelets 280,000/mm3 Leukocytes 14,400/mm3 Serum chemistry Blood urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL He is initially treated with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. Forty-eight hours later, blood cultures from admission grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. What is the best next step in management of this patient's infection?
explanation: This patient has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia in the setting of a relatively recent hospitalization and cardiovascular procedure. Echocardiography is recommended for all patients with S aureus bacteremia due to the high risk of associated metastatic complications. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) should be performed first, although a transesophageal echocardiogram is more sensitive in detecting valve vegetations and could be considered if there is no evidence of vegetations on TTE. (Choices A and B) The routine addition of gentamicin or rifampin is not recommended in cases of MRSA bacteremia. Gentamicin is sometimes added to shorter courses of penicillin therapy for selected patients with native-valve endocarditis due to penicillin-susceptible strains. Some guidelines recommend adding rifampin to vancomycin in patients with a penicillin allergy who are being treated for methicillin-susceptible native-valve endocarditis. (Choice C) Colonoscopy is recommended in cases of bacteremia caused by Streptococcus gallolyticus due to a strong association with colonic malignancy. There is no association between MRSA bacteremia and colonic lesions. (Choice E) Although metastatic complications to the eye can occur with MRSA bacteremia, they are uncommon, and ophthalmologic evaluation in a patient without visual symptoms is generally not recommended. In contrast, all patients with candidemia should undergo ophthalmologic evaluation. Educational objective: Echocardiography should be performed in all patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia regardless of the presence of clinical signs suggestive of endocarditis.

stem: A 51-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to fever and generalized weakness. She was diagnosed with metastatic ovarian cancer 3 months ago and is on systemic chemotherapy after undergoing cytoreduction surgery. Cycle 2 of chemotherapy was completed 10 days ago. The patient initially had nausea and vomiting but was feeling better the last few days. However, yesterday afternoon she became quite fatigued, and this morning she had a temperature of 39.1 C (102.4 F). Her oncologist recommended a visit to the emergency department for evaluation. The patient has had no sore throat, sinus pain, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. She has no other chronic medical problems but had prolonged neutropenia after her first cycle of chemotherapy. She does not use tobacco or alcohol and has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 38.6 C (101.5F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min and regular, and respirations are 20/min. Pulse oximetry shows 96% on room air. The patient is alert and cooperative. No lymphadenopathy is present. There is no skin rash or erythema or tenderness around the subcutaneous venous access device. Lungs are clear to auscultation, and no heart murmurs are present. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 10.0 g/dL Platelets 40,000/mm3 Leukocytes 600/mm3 Neutrophils 15% Serum chemistry Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL Chest-x ray reveals no new parenchymal opacities or pleural effusion. Urinalysis reveals no pyuria. Two sets of blood cultures are drawn and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
explanation: This patient with ovarian cancer who recently received chemotherapy has febrile neutropenia, which is generally defined as a temperature >38.3 C (>101 F) and an absolute neutrophil count <500/mm. Most cases are due to gram-positive pathogens such as Staphylococcus epidermidis (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, and streptococci, but gram-negative bacteria (eg, Pseudomonas) are isolated in approximately 25% of cases and are often associated with more severe illness. Monotherapy with an anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (eg, piperacillin-tazobactam, cefepime) or a carbapenem is considered first-line treatment in the inpatient setting. Studies have shown no improvement in mortality with the routine addition of a second agent (eg, vancomycin) targeting gram-positive pathogens (Choice A). Indications for vancomycin include: Hemodynamic instability; Severe sepsis; Pneumonia; Positive blood cultures for a gram-positive organism (prior to speciation results); Suspected catheter-related infection (eg, chills during infusion, cellulitis around entry site); Skin or soft-tissue infection. (Choice B) Ceftazidime plus ciprofloxacin are sometimes used in combination to double cover potential Pseudomonas infections. However, Pseudomonas double coverage is controversial and typically reserved for those who are severely ill (eg, patients with sepsis/septic shock, burn patients with severe infection) and at high risk for multidrug-resistant infections. Ceftazidime monotherapy should be avoided in neutropenic fever due to rising resistance in gram-negative bacteria and limited activity against gram-positive organisms (eg, viridans streptococci). Adding ciprofloxacin may improve gram-negative coverage but would not provide better gram-positive coverage. (Choice D) Empiric antifungal treatment for febrile neutropenia is generally reserved for patients who have been febrile >4-7 days, those who are undergoing intensive induction chemotherapy for acute leukemia, or those who have recently undergone hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. (Choice E) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be used to treat urinary tract and skin/soft-tissue infections but is not a mainstay antibiotic for febrile neutropenia. Low-risk febrile neutropenia can be treated with oral ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate. Educational objective: Hospitalized patients with neutropenic fever should generally receive monotherapy with an anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (eg, piperacillin-tazobactam) or a carbapenem. The routine addition of a second agent (eg, vancomycin) targeting gram-positive pathogens is not recommended.

stem: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department and reports, "I think I have pinkeye." He was feeling well until 4 days ago when he developed fever, malaise, rhinorrhea, and a dry cough. He then noticed bilateral eye redness, irritation, and mucoid drainage. A red rash formed on his neck and trunk yesterday morning and spread to his face by the evening. The patient has no ill family members but recently returned from a missionary trip to Bangladesh. He is up to date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min Examination shows conjunctival erythema and edema. Small white papules are present on the buccal mucosa. Chest is clear to auscultation. Skin examination shows an erythematous, maculopapular rash that blanches on palpation, as shown in the exhibit. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum chemistry Blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 76 U/L Complete blood count Hemoglobin 14 g/dL Leukocytes 3,000/mm3 Platelets 120,000/mm3 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's illness?
choice_b: Obtain cerebrospinal fluid for Gram stain and culture
choice_d: Order rapid antigen testing for malarial parasite
explanation: This patient who recently traveled to Bangladesh likely has measles. Measles is rare in the United States due to widespread vaccination efforts, but sporadic cases and outbreaks have been linked to travelers returning from endemic regions. Most cases arise in unvaccinated individuals as a single dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine is 93% protective and 2 doses (full vaccination) are 97% protective. However, vaccinated individuals can rarely develop the disease due to vaccine failure or waned immunity. Patients with measles infection usually pass through the following stages: Prodrome: Fever, malaise, and anorexia followed by the "3 Cs" of cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza. Koplik spots, small white-grey-blue lesions on an erythematous base, frequently form on the buccal and/or labial mucosa. Exanthem: Begins 2-4 days after fever onset and is characterized by an erythematous, macular, blanching rash that usually starts on the face and spreads in a cephalocaudal and centrifugal manner. Recovery: Clinical improvement usually begins within 48 hours of rash onset. However, complications, including diarrhea, immunosuppression with severe secondary infection, pneumonia, and/or neurologic disease (eg, encephalitis, subacute sclerosing panencephalitis), arise in up to 30% of cases. Patients with suspected measles infections require serum and throat/nasopharyngeal swab testing for measles IgM or RT-PCR. Treatment is largely supportive as no antiviral therapy is currently available. Measles is transmitted by droplet nuclei (which can remain suspended in the air for up to 2 hours) so airborne isolation is required for at least 4 days after rash onset; close contacts should be advised to wear masks or respirators. (Choice B) Cerebrospinal fluid analysis would be indicated for potential meningococcal infection, which typically presents within 24 hours (not 4 days) of symptom onset with fever, malaise, myalgias, headache, meningeal signs, and/or hemodynamic instability. Rash can occur but is typically petechial (nonblanching). (Choice C) Mononucleosis can cause fever, malaise, and maculopapular rash (usually after the administration of amoxicillin). However, most cases are also marked by tonsillitis/pharyngitis and cervical lymphadenopathy. Coryza, conjunctivitis, and white buccal lesions make measles more likely. (Choice D) Malaria often causes paroxysmal fever, nonspecific symptoms, and splenomegaly. Conjunctivitis, coryza, Koplik spots, and a maculopapular rash are not typical features. (Choice E) Doxycycline can be used to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a tickborne illness that initially causes fever and nonspecific symptoms. Rash typically forms on day 3-5 and is blanching and erythematous, becomes petechial over time, and moves in a centripetal direction (starts on the wrists and ankles and moves centrally). This patient with a central rash and Koplik spots is more likely to have measles. Educational objective: Measles infections tend to begin with fever, malaise, and anorexia followed by the "3 Cs" of cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza. Koplik spots (white lesions on an erythematous base) then form on mucous membranes, followed by the characteristic exanthem (maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal and centrifugal manner). Measles is highly infectious and transmitted by droplet nuclei, so airborne isolation is required for at least 4 days after rash onset.

stem: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to skin rash that he noticed this morning on his arms and legs. He has also had fever and headache for 3 days. The patient had a root canal 2 weeks ago with mild post-procedure pain and gum swelling. Medical history is otherwise noncontributory. He is an avid biker who enjoys spending time outdoors. The patient does not use alcohol or tobacco. He has a male partner with whom he has been in a stable relationship for the last 2 years. Temperature is 39.7 C (103.5 F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 114/min and regular. No lymph node enlargement is present. There is no sinus tenderness to palpation. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There are no heart murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nontender, and the tip of the spleen is not palpated. Maculopapular rash with petechiae is present on the arms and legs. There are no meningeal signs. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL Hematocrit 35% Platelets 90,000/mm3 Leukocytes 11,000/mm3 Serum chemistry Sodium 134 mEq/L Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Chloride 106 mEq/L Bicarbonate 22 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Liver function studies Total protein 4.0 g/dL Albumin 2.2 g/dL Total bilirubin 1.3 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 162 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 174 U/L Two blood smears are negative for potential blood-borne pathogens. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's high fever, headache, and extremity rash raise suspicion for Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF). RMSF is a potentially lethal tick-borne illness due to Rickettsia rickettsii. Although RMSF can occur throughout the United States, it is most common in the southeastern region. Peak incidence is in the spring and summer. Manifestations usually begin with nonspecific symptoms (eg, fever, severe headache, malaise, myalgias, arthralgias) followed 3-5 days later by a maculopapular rash that becomes petechial over time. The rash typically starts on the ankles and wrists and spreads centrally to the trunk and peripherally to the palms and soles. Hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum transaminases are important diagnostic clues. Identifying potential cases of RMSF is often challenging because approximately 35% of patients have no knowledge of tick bite and only 15% of patients have a rash at presentation. A minority (~10%) never develop a rash ("spotless" RMSF). Because of these difficulties, empiric first-line treatment with doxycycline is typically administered to patients who develop a nonspecific febrile illness in the spring and summer if they are from an endemic area and have had known or possible tick exposure. Early treatment is crucial as antibiotic initiation ≥5 days after symptom onset is associated with much higher risk of morbidity (eg, encephalitis, gangrene of the digits) and death. The diagnosis is usually confirmed several days later with serology or skin biopsy (after the rash appears). (Choice B) Meningococcemia can also cause headache, fever, and a petechial rash, but most cases come to clinical attention <24 hours after symptom onset and are also associated with confusion and meningeal signs (eg, nuchal rigidity). If early meningococcemia cannot be differentiated from RMSF, patients sometimes require a combination of empiric ceftriaxone and doxycycline while awaiting cerebrospinal fluid results. (Choice C) Mononucleosis can cause high fever and a rash (usually after antibiotic administration), but patients also typically have sore throat, lymphadenopathy, malaise, and/or splenomegaly. (Choice D) Secondary syphilis can also cause a maculopapular rash that involves the palms and soles but is not usually associated with high fevers. Patients who may have secondary syphilis but are at risk for RMSF should be treated with doxycycline while syphilis serology is pending. (Choice E) Infective endocarditis can cause high fever and skin manifestations (eg, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes), but a maculopapular rash on the bilateral extremities would be atypical. Educational objective: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a tick-borne rickettsial illness that causes nonspecific symptoms followed by a maculopapular rash 3-5 days later. The rash typically starts on the ankles and wrists and spreads centrally to the trunk and peripherally to the palms and soles. Empiric therapy with doxycycline should be started as soon as possible to decrease morbidity and mortality.

stem: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with generalized tonic-clonic seizures. His wife states that he had a similar episode a month ago but did not seek medical attention. The patient emigrated from Mexico several years ago and is HIV-negative. On examination, he is lethargic but moves all extremities on command. A CT scan of the head reveals several small cystic lesions in the cortex bilaterally as well as scattered focal areas of calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This Hispanic immigrant likely has neurocysticercosis, an important cause of seizure in individuals from endemic areas (eg, Central and South America). Neurocysticercosis occurs from ingestion of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) eggs shed in the stool of human tapeworm carriers. Over a period of weeks, cysts can develop in the brain parenchyma (most common), intraventricular or subarachnoid space, spine, and/or eyes. After the asymptomatic viable phase (~3-5 years), cysts degenerate and can no longer evade host defenses. Inflammation causes neurologic symptoms depending on the site and extent of brain involvement. Parenchymal brain disease typically presents with seizure and headache. Neuroimaging (eg, CT or MRI) may demonstrate multiple stages of cysts concurrently, which tend to lodge in the cerebral cortex or brainstem. Viable cysts appear as 5-20 mm round, hypodense lesions without contrast enhancement. Inflammation and edema may be apparent as the cysts degenerate, and eventually, calcified granulomas may form. Treatment generally includes antiparasitics (eg, albendazole) and/or corticosteroids. (Choice B) Glioblastoma multiforme usually appears as a large solitary tumor within the cerebral hemisphere with irregular-enhancing margins and a central necrotic core. The tumor also tends to spread across white matter tracts such as the corpus callosum (eg, butterfly glioma). (Choice C) Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors rarely metastasize to the brain, but when present, these typically appear as multiple lesions at the junction of gray and white matter, usually with significant surrounding edema. (Choice D) Cerebral toxoplasmosis is rare in immunocompetent hosts. However, in HIV-infected patients, it can cause encephalitis (eg, headache, confusion, fever) and appear as multiple ring-enhancing lesions on neuroimaging. (Choice E) Central nervous system tuberculosis usually presents with a subacute febrile illness followed by meningismus, focal deficits, confusion, and seizure. Neuroimaging may reveal basilar meningeal enhancement, hydrocephalus, and tuberculomas (iso- or hyperdense encapsulated lesions with ring enhancement). The absence of systemic symptoms or characteristic neuroimaging makes the diagnosis less likely in this patient. Educational objective: Neurocysticercosis is an important cause of seizure in individuals from endemic areas (eg, Central and South America, sub-Saharan Africa), including Hispanic immigrants. Neuroimaging (eg, CT or MRI) may reveal viable cysts (5-20 mm round, hypodense lesions without enhancement), enhancement/edema as cysts degenerate, and calcified granulomas in the cortex or brainstem.

stem: A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fevers, cough, and headache. The headache has worsened over the last week with localization to the right side and is associated with nausea. Yesterday he noted left-hand weakness and difficulty grasping objects. He has no history of travel outside of the northeastern United States or exposure to domestic animals or sick contacts. The patient underwent liver transplantation for primary biliary cirrhosis 8 months ago and had an uneventful postoperative course. His medications include prednisone and tacrolimus. His preoperative tuberculin skin testing was negative and he has had no postoperative infections. He is physically active and had walked 2-3 miles a day until 1 week ago. His temperature is 38.2 C (100.8 F), blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. Crackles are present over the right upper lung field. There are no heart murmurs. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. There are no skin rashes. Neurological examination is notable for left-hand weakness and decreased sensation of the left hand and forearm. Chest x-ray reveals patchy alveolar opacities in the right upper lobe and a 3-cm abscess in the right middle lobe. Head CT scan shows an abscess in the right cerebral hemisphere. A transesophageal echocardiogram reveals no vegetations. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with this patient's clinical presentation?
explanation: This patient with lung and CNS disease after organ transplantation has likely nocardiosis. Nocardia is found in the soil and can enter the body through inhalation or direct contact with soil. Because it is not part of normal human flora, isolation of the organism from any bodily fluids (eg, sputum) is considered an infection. Patients usually present with lung (primary site) infection. Nocardia has special tropism to neural tissue, and usually manifests as brain abscess. Immunocompromised patients presenting with pulmonary nocardiosis should therefore undergo brain imaging to rule out abscess. Diagnosis of nocardiosis is made clinically with symptoms and partially acid-fast, branching rods isolated in specimens. Aerobic cultures for Nocardia can take 5-20 days for growth. PCR testing for Nocardia is more rapid and accurate but is not widely available. Nonsevere cutaneous nocardiosis can be treated with oral antibiotics (eg, TMP-SMX); systemic disease requires IV antibiotics. Patients usually require antibiotics for prolonged periods due to the relapsing nature of the infection. Immunocompromised patients may require lifelong suppressive therapy with TMP-SMX or doxycycline. (Choice A) In contrast to Nocardia, Actinomyces is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod that is part of normal oral flora and contains sulfur granules. Actinomyces most commonly affects the face (usually after dental work/infections or oromaxillary trauma) and abdominal organs. CNS and pulmonary actinomycosis are less common. (Choice B) Atypical mycobacterial infections usually present with chronic pulmonary symptoms or soft-tissue infections but rarely become disseminated or involve the CNS. (Choice D) This patient's absence of known predisposing factors and vegetations on TEE makes endocarditis less likely. (Choice E) Toxoplasma gondii most commonly affects the CNS (95%) and rarely affects the lungs. Most infections occur due to reactivation of latent infection. CT usually shows multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions with surrounding edema, most commonly in the basal ganglia. Educational objective: Nocardia is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients and typically involves the lung, brain, and skin. Diagnosis is made clinically and confirmed with culture isolating acid-fast, filamentous Gram-positive rods. Treatment involves TMP-SMX, imipenem, amikacin, or third-generation cephalosporins.

stem: An 82-year-old nursing home resident with a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to the emergency department after 2 days of fever, cough, and lethargy. He was treated with acetaminophen at the nursing home, but was found to be very confused this morning. His oral intake has also been poor. His daily medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and tiotropium. He has never been hospitalized for a COPD exacerbation or pneumonia. At the nursing home, there have been two cases of mild febrile illness over the past two weeks. In the emergency department, he is ill-appearing and obtunded. His temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 107/60 mm Hg, pulse is 68/min and respirations are 26/min. Pulmonary examination reveals crackles at the left lung base. Bowel sounds are hyperactive and his abdomen is soft. There are no meningeal signs present. Laboratory studies reveal: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL Hematocrit 34% Platelets 120,000/µL Leukocyte count 14,000 cells/µL Neutrophils 80% Serum chemistry Sodium 128 mEq/L Potassium 4.2 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 30 mg/dL Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL Liver function studies Total protein 5.0 g/dL Albumin 2.5 g/dL Bilirubin, total 1.8 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 140 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 146 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 114 U/L A chest x ray reveals an ill-defined infiltrate at the left lung base. Piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin are started empirically. Over the next 48 hours, his clinical status continues to deteriorate. A repeat chest x ray reveals progressive infiltrates with worsening left lower lobe consolidation. This patient's condition is most likely to respond to which of the following?
explanation: This patient's underlying risk factors (elderly age, COPD, nursing home resident), clinical presentation (confusion, high fever with bradycardia), laboratory abnormalities (hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia, elevated LFTs), and failure to respond to vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam are strongly suggestive of Legionella pneumonia. Legionella species are facultative intracellular gram-negative bacilli whose natural habitats are aquatic bodies (e.g., lakes, streams, man-made reservoirs, standing water). There are no pathognomonic or highly specific clinical, laboratory, or radiological features for Legionella infection. The most common x-ray finding is a unilobar infiltrate that progresses to consolidation. Patients with suspected Legionella pneumonia should have both a urinary Legionella antigen test (detects only L. pneumophila, serogroup 1) and a respiratory sample (e.g., sputum, BAL) for Legionella culture. Suspected or proven Legionella pneumonia requires treatment with a respiratory fluoroquinolone (e.g.. levofloxacin) or "newer" macrolide (e.g., azithromycin), as both have good lung penetration with potent intracellular activity. (Choice A) Ampicillin and piperacillin-tazobactam are both beta-lactam antibiotics and are ineffective against Legionella. Ampicillin is commonly used to treat Listeria, which causes meningitis/sepsis but not pneumonia. (Choice C) Linezolid is approved for treating MRSA pneumonia and is as effective as vancomycin. However, vancomycin and linezolid are not effective against Legionella. (Choice D) Metronidazole is effective for anaerobic aspiration pneumonia but not for Legionella. (Choice E) Oseltamivir treats primary influenza pneumonia, which more commonly shows bilateral reticular or reticulonodular opacities. Educational objective: Legionella pneumonia usually presents with fever, relative bradycardia, possible neurologic and GI symptoms, and potential unilobar chest x-ray infiltrate progressing to consolidation. Suspected patients with Legionella pneumonia should have both a urinary antigen test and a Legionella culture from a respiratory sample to confirm diagnosis. Treatment consists of respiratory fluoroquinolones (e.g.. levofloxacin) or "newer" macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) while awaiting results.

stem: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a cough, malaise, skin rash, and migratory joint pain that began 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he returned from a hiking trip in the southwestern United States. The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed 2 years ago, which has been in remission since infliximab was started 6 months ago. His tuberculin skin testing was negative 7 months ago. On examination, temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 14/min. There are several tender, erythematous nodules 2-3 cm in size in both legs over the anterior shins. Oropharyngeal mucosa is dry without any erythema or exudate. On auscultation, fine basal crackles are heard on the left side. There is synovitis and tenderness of both knee joints. The rest of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show white blood cells are 16,000/mm3 (72% neutrophils) and platelets are 650,000/mm3 Chest x-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation of cough, fever, arthralgia, and erythema nodosum after recent travel to the southwestern United States is consistent with coccidioidomycosis. In immunocompetent hosts, Coccidioides immitis may be asymptomatic or cause only a minor febrile respiratory syndrome ("valley fever"). However, in immunocompromised patients, C immitis can also cause acute pneumonia (most common), chronic progressive pneumonia, nodular or cavitary lung disease, extrapulmonary disease, or meningitis. Patients receiving tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitors, such as infliximab, are at increased risk for opportunistic fungal infections. Diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis is primarily based on epidemiologic (ie, travel) history and clinical findings, and is confirmed with culture, microscopy (potassium hydroxide preparation), or serology. Most patients with valley fever improve without therapy; however, fluconazole or itraconazole should be considered for those with evidence of severe infection or immunosuppression. (Choice B) Hodgkin lymphoma most commonly presents with painless cervical adenopathy. Systemic symptoms may develop as the disorder progresses and adenopathy develops in contiguous areas (eg, mediastinum). This patient does not have lymphadenopathy. (Choice C) Sarcoidosis may present similarly to coccidioidomycosis with cough, fever, joint pain, and erythema nodosum. However, pulmonary involvement is present in >90% of patients with sarcoidosis, and most patients will have abnormal findings on chest x-ray (eg, hilar adenopathy). (Choices D and E) Although tuberculosis and tularemia may have varied presentations, this patient's negative tuberculin skin test, normal chest x-ray, and lack of relevant exposure history (eg, farm exposure or small animal handling for tularemia) make them less likely. Educational objective: Cough, fever, arthritis, and erythema nodosum after recent travel to the southwestern United States is consistent with coccidioidomycosis. Patients receiving tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitors are at increased risk for opportunistic infections, including fungal pathogens.

stem: A 71-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of excruciating left thigh pain, weakness, and nausea. His medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He is a lifetime non-smoker. His blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg and pulse is 114/min and regular. Mucous membranes are dry. Examination reveals magenta-bronze discoloration, crepitus, tenderness, and significant swelling over the left thigh. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 12.2 g/dL Platelets 350,000 cells/µL Leukocyte count 17,500 cells/µL Serum chemistry Potassium 5.3 mEq/L Bicarbonate 14 mEq/L Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL (baseline 2.4 mg/dL) A Foley catheter was placed and 200 mL of concentrated urine was drained. Intravenous antibiotics, analgesics, and bolus fluids were administered. CT scan of the thigh showed gas gangrene. He was emergently taken to the operating room for debridement. Four days later, the patient feels better. The Foley catheter is removed and he urinates without difficulty. Two sets of blood cultures sent on admission grow Clostridium septicum. Which of the following additional studies would be indicated in this patient?
explanation: Clostridium septicum is commonly associated with spontaneous gas gangrene. Unlike other Clostridium species (e.g., Clostridium perfringens), a history of trauma is not required for infection. Infection usually spreads hematogenously from GI tract pathology. Most patients have underlying colonic malignancy, but other conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease and diverticulitis have also been associated with C. septicum infection. Thus, all patients with C. septicum bacteremia should be evaluated with colonoscopy. (Choice B to E) Clostridium septicum is not usually associated with lung, bladder, prostate, or cardiac pathology. Educational objective: Clostridium septicum usually presents with bacteremia followed by spontaneous gas gangrene in an extremity without a history of trauma. Since the bacteria originates in the Gl tract and is associated with GI pathology (e.g., colon cancer), all patients with C. septicum bacteremia should undergo a colonoscopy.

stem: A 21-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to fever and headache. The patient began having myalgias 12 hours ago and then rapidly developed fever, progressive headache, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. She has had no cough, dyspnea, diarrhea, or dysuria. The patient has no prior medical issues and takes no medications. She is a college student and lives in a dormitory on campus. She has not traveled recently and does not know if she has been exposed to sick contacts. The patient drinks 2-4 beers on weekends and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Temperature is 39.2 C (102.7 F), blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. The patient is ill-appearing with scattered petechial skin rash. No sinus tenderness is present, and the oropharyngeal mucosa is moist with no lesions. Auscultation of the heart and lungs is normal. She has neck rigidity but no other focal neurological deficits. Funduscopy shows no papilledema. Which of the following infection-control measures is most appropriate at the present time for this patient?
choice_b: Placement in a room with negative air pressure
choice_d: Strict use of soap and water for hand hygiene
choice_e: Wearing surgical mask in the vicinity of the patient
explanation: Neisseria meningitidis is the leading cause of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in children and young adults. Most cases begin with severe myalgias followed by a petechial/hemorrhagic rash, fever, and meningeal signs. Patients often deteriorate rapidly and usually present ≤24 hours after symptom onset. N meningitidis is transmitted by aerosolized droplets and is highly contagious; all patients with suspected meningococcal meningitis should be put on droplet precautions for at least 24 hours after the initiation of antimicrobial therapy. As part of these precautions, health care personnel should wear surgical masks when they are within 6 feet of the patient. (Choice A) Contact precautions are typically used to prevent spread of multidrug resistant bacteria (eg, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) and some enteric organisms such as Clostridium difficile. Gloves and gowns are required for interaction with the patient. (Choice B) Airborne isolation involves a negative air pressure room and is typically used for organisms that are transmitted by airborne droplet nuclei (<5 microns) such as tuberculosis, varicella, and measles. Droplet nuclei are smaller than aerosolized droplets and can stay suspended in the air for several hours; as such, droplet nuclei require airborne isolation whereas aerosolized droplets do not. (Choice C) Standard precautions should be used in the care of all patients and include hand hygiene, gowns/glove/eye protection if exposure to fluids is likely, and safe injection practices. This patient with likely meningococcal meningitis requires droplet precautions in addition to standard precautions. (Choice D) Potential C difficile infection requires the use of soap and water for hand hygiene as alcohol-based hand rubs do not eradicate C difficile spores. This patient does not have watery diarrhea or risk factors for C difficile (eg, recent antimicrobial therapy). Educational objective: Patients with potential meningococcal meningitis require at least 24 hours of droplet precautions after the initiation of antibiotics in order to prevent transmission to individuals in close contact. Droplet precautions include the use of a surgical mask when an individual is within 6 feet of the source patients.

stem: A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 1-day history of chills, headache, and muscle aches. A week ago, she returned from a month-long trip to Tanzania. During her travels, she stayed with friends in local hotels and ate mostly at local restaurants. She spent significant time outdoors, including swimming in local lakes. She had taken atovaquone-proguanil for malaria prophylaxis and was compliant with therapy. The patient's temperature is 38 C (100.4 F). Physical examination shows multiple urticaria-type lesions on the trunk and upper extremities. Laboratory studies are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 13 g/dL Hematocrit 39% Platelets 300,000/mm3 Leukocytes 12,000 cells/mm3 Eosinophils 40% Serum chemistry Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Acute onset of fevers, allergic-type symptoms (urticarial lesions, angioedema), and robust eosinophilia in the setting of a recent trip to sub-Saharan Africa with freshwater exposure is suggestive of acute schistosomiasis syndrome (Katayama fever). This is a systemic hypersensitivity reaction against schistosomal eggs and larvae, typically occurring 14-28 days after infection. Chest x-ray infiltrates may be present. Microscopic examination for schistosomiasis eggs and serologic testing may be negative in acute schistosomiasis. The episode is usually self-limiting (days to weeks), and management is with corticosteroids during the acute phase followed by antihelminthic therapy (eg, praziquantel) to prevent long-term sequelae of helminth infection (eg, hydronephrosis, bladder squamous cell carcinoma). (Choice A) Amebiasis typically manifests with nonspecific or gastrointestinal symptoms (flatulence, diarrhea, lactose intolerance, malabsorption). Fever would be rare. (Choice B) Unremitting high fevers and severe polyarthralgia would be more characteristic of Chikungunya fever. (Choice C) Cutaneous leishmaniasis is due to a protozoan parasite transmitted to humans via sandfly bites. It usually presents as a nonpruritic red papule that forms an ulcer with granulomatous tissue at the base and raised margins. (Choice D) Malaria is not classically associated with urticarial lesions or eosinophilia. This patient's normal hemoglobin and platelet counts and her compliance with prophylaxis make malaria a less likely diagnosis. Educational objective: Consider acute schistosomiasis (Katayama fever) among patients presenting with fever and eosinophilia after return from an endemic area, including sub-Saharan Africa. Corticosteroids and supportive care are indicated in the acute setting followed by antiparasitic treatment after acute symptoms resolve.

stem: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy and fever. He called his daughter this morning and told her that he had been having fever, chills, and headache. When she visited him a few hours later, he was warm to the touch and lethargic and soon had a tonic-clonic seizure. The patient is a widower who lives independently and is in excellent health. He has no history of previous seizure and has not recently traveled. He does not use alcohol or tobacco and has no allergies. Temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 20/min. Pulse oximetry shows 96% on room air. The patient is lethargic and oriented only to person. He responds intermittently to questions but moves all 4 extremities on command. Moderate neck pain and stiffness are present. Deep-tendon reflexes are symmetric. No genital lesions are noted. Laboratory workup is obtained and head CT scan and lumbar puncture are planned. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
