explanation: This older patient has all 3 classic manifestations (high fever, neck stiffness, altered mental state) of acute bacterial meningitis. Most cases are due to Streptococcus pneumoniae (~70%), but Neisseria meningitidis, group B streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae, and Listeria monocytogenes (in those age >50) are also common culprits. The underlying organism is typically identified by blood and/or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures. Patients with suspected acute bacterial meningitis require urgent empiric treatment to limit neurologic sequelae and reduce the risk of death. First-line antibiotic therapy includes ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and ampicillin (added for those age >50 to empirically cover L monocytogenes). In addition, dexamethasone is given just prior to or with the first dose of empiric antibiotics to reduce neurologic sequelae (eg, hearing loss) and mortality in those with pneumococcal meningitis; it should be discontinued if CSF gram stain or culture (or blood culture) indicates infection with a nonpneumococcal organism. Most patients are initiated on treatment after blood cultures and lumbar puncture. However, those who require a head CT scan prior to lumbar puncture (eg, altered mental state, new seizure, focal deficit, immunocompromise, central nervous system disease, papilledema) should first receive empiric therapy to limit treatment delays. (Choice A) Acyclovir is used to treat herpes encephalitis, which commonly presents with high fever, altered mental status, seizure, and/or focal neurologic deficits but is rarely associated with neck stiffness or nuchal rigidity. Most (85%) cases of herpes meningitis are accompanied by genital lesions. Compared to bacterial meningitis, herpes central nervous system (CNS) infections are less likely to cause marked hypotension (as seen in this patient) in the absence of immunosuppression. Although patients undergoing empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis sometimes receive concurrent empiric acyclovir therapy until herpes CNS infection is ruled out, acyclovir would not be used alone. (Choices B and D) Cefepime or meropenem are used in place of ceftriaxone for the empiric treatment of bacterial meningitis when patients have underlying immunocompromise or health care-associated meningitis (eg, head trauma, recent neurosurgery) to cover for opportunistic bacterial pathogens such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This patient has no evidence of immunocompromise or risk for health care-associated meningitis. (Choice E) Because this patient is age >50, he requires ampicillin to cover for L monocytogenes. In addition, dexamethasone is required to reduce adverse outcomes in the setting of possible pneumococcal meningitis. Educational objective: Patients with suspected acute bacterial meningitis require urgent empiric treatment with ceftriaxone and vancomycin. Ampicillin should be added for those age >50 to empirically cover for Listeria monocytogenes. All patients should also receive adjunctive dexamethasone to reduce risk of neurologic sequelae and death from potential pneumococcal meningitis.

stem: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash on her forehead. The rash has been present for 3 days and is getting worse. She also complains of moderate frontal headache, malaise, and fever. The patient has no neck pain, nausea, or vomiting. She has not had similar symptoms before. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her temperature is 38.5 C (101.3 F). Her forehead is shown in the photograph below. In addition to admission to the hospital and intravenous acyclovir, which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient presents with headache, malaise, fever, and a skin rash, all highly suggestive of herpes zoster. The vesicular, crusty skin eruption on her forehead also involves the eyelids, with evidence of edema and drooping. She is at risk of developing herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO). HZO is a serious, vision-threatening complication of reactivation of varicella zoster virus in the trigeminal nerve root ganglion. Some patients present with headache, malaise, eye pain, and fever before developing a rash on the face. Once the rash develops, patients can also have conjunctivitis, keratitis, or episcleritis. Vesicles near the nose are also associated with a high risk of HZO. Patients at risk for herpes zoster ophthalmicus require an urgent ophthalmology consultation. Immunocompromised patients with sight-threatening ophthalmicus should receive intravenous acyclovir. When urgent evaluation by an ophthalmologist is not available, topical steroid eye drops can be used to decrease the inflammatory response. (Choices A & E) Gabapentin and topical capsaicin can provide relief from pain of post-herpetic neuralgia, defined as persistent pain after resolution of the initial rash. However, these agents are not helpful for pain from acute neuritis. (Choice B) The risk of aseptic meningitis is higher in immunocompromised than immunocompetent (0.5%) individuals. This patient has no meningeal signs or risk factors for immunosuppression; hence, a lumbar puncture is not needed at this time. (Choice D) Systemic glucocorticoids, when used in combination with antiviral therapy for treatment of herpes zoster, can increase the risk of secondary bacterial skin infections. They are not recommended in this patient. Educational objective: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a serious, vision-threatening complication of latent varicella zoster virus infection. Treatment consists of intravenous acyclovir and urgent ophthalmologic evaluation.

stem: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to cramping abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia, and multiple episodes of loose stools for the last 2 days. The patient is a medical student who returned from rural Indonesia a week ago after volunteering at a hospital for a month. Several days into his travel, he experienced watery diarrhea that spontaneously resolved within a few days. After his return, he had fever and sore throat for which his primary care physician prescribed amoxicillin, which he finished taking 2 days ago. The patient has no chronic medical conditions, takes no other medications, and has no known allergies. His older brother has ulcerative colitis and his mother has hypertension. Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 94/45 mm Hg, and pulse is 112/min and regular. The abdomen is soft and diffusely tender with maximum tenderness in the right lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL Platelets 450,000/mm3 Leukocytes 26,000/mm3 Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL C-reactive protein 64 mg/L (<0.3 mg/L) Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
explanation: This patient's presentation (loose stools, abdominal pain, and significant leukocytosis developing days after antibiotic therapy) is most consistent with a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). C difficile can present in a variety of ways (Table), but it usually colonizes normal gut flora altered by antibiotic use. Symptoms typically start during antibiotic therapy or 5-10 days afterward. Penicillins, fluoroquinolones, and clindamycin are most commonly associated with CDI; however, virtually any antibiotic may be involved. Lower abdominal tenderness, nausea, anorexia, and diarrhea with mucus or occult blood are common presentations. Diagnosis is suggested by clinical findings and recent antibiotic use; C difficile stool studies can be confirmatory. If there is high clinical suspicion, empiric treatment with oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin can be considered when awaiting test results. Fulminant disease (eg, hypotension, ileus, megacolon) requires the addition of intravenous metronidazole to high dose-vancomycin. Patients who are refractory to treatment may need further evaluation with colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy; however, extreme caution should be used in patients with fulminant colitis due to perforation risk. (Choice A) Appendicitis most commonly presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, anorexia, and nausea/vomiting. However, this patient has had multiple episodes of loose stools over the past 2 days, and his abdomen is soft and diffusely tender (without rebound tenderness, making peritonitis less likely). This presentation makes infectious diarrhea with colitis more likely than appendicitis. (Choice C) Endotoxin-producing Shigella usually presents with bloody, mucoid diarrhea; fever and abdominal pain. It resolves spontaneously in most patients. This patient's current episode of diarrhea is more likely due to C difficile given the high degree of leukocytosis; lack of bloody, mucoid diarrhea; and timing of symptoms shortly after antibiotic use. (Choice D) The majority (~90%) of Entamoeba histolytica infections are asymptomatic, whereas symptomatic patients have bloody diarrhea with abdominal pain. Symptoms usually have a subacute onset over 1-3 weeks. (Choice E) Inflammatory bowel disease usually presents with the gradual onset of diarrhea after previous self-limited episodes of rectal bleeding/diarrhea. This patient's timing of symptoms following antibiotic use makes this less likely. Educational objective: Clostridium difficile infection usually presents with multiple episodes of watery diarrhea after recent antibiotic use. Diagnosis is confirmed by stool studies, and treatment involves oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin. Patients refractory to treatment may need further investigation with sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy.

stem: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department after 1 week of fever, chills, and headache. He also complains of nausea and an episode of vomiting. He has no abdominal pain or diarrhea. Three weeks ago, he returned from travelling in southern Africa, where he volunteered at a medical clinic in rural Malawi for 3 months. He took doxycycline for the entire trip until returning to the United States. He drank mostly bottled water but did eat local cooked food. He had no sexual activity, injected drug use, or freshwater exposure during his travels. His temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 18/min. He is uncomfortable but nontoxic-appearing. There is no skin rash. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive and there is mild scleral icterus but no conjunctival lesions or suffusion. There is no neck stiffness or meningeal signs. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the left upper quadrant and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 9.3 g/dL Hematocrit 28% Platelets 70,000/µL Leukocytes 11,800/µL Neutrophils 76% Lymphocytes 22% Eosinophils 2% Serum chemistry Sodium 136 mEq/L Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Chloride 111 mEq/L Bicarbonate 22 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 32 mg/dL Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL Creatinine kinase 110 U/L Which test is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
choice_e: Stool sample for ova and parasites
explanation: This patient with recent travel to Sub-Saharan Africa has an acute-onset febrile illness, scleral icterus, mild splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. This presentation is most consistent with malaria. Plasmodium falciparum accounts for the majority of deaths from malaria, followed by Plasmodium vivax. Many of the clinical symptoms seen in malaria are due to the infected parasite-containing red blood cells adhering to nearby vessels, causing small infarcts, leakage of capillaries, and, ultimately, organ dysfunction. Diagnosis is confirmed with examination of a peripheral blood smear looking for trophozoites. Commonly used malaria prophylaxis drugs (eg, chloroquine, mefloquine, and doxycycline) target the blood stage of the parasite (blood schizonticides) when released from the liver. Tissue schizonticides (eg, atovaquone/proguanil) are designed to target the liver stage, where the parasites grow and can stay dormant in the liver (or other tissues). The blood schizonticides must be continued for at least 4 weeks after leaving an endemic area to ensure eradication of parasites released from the liver. This patient did take doxycycline for malaria prophylaxis but discontinued his medication on return to the United States, causing it to be ineffective. (Choice A) Blood culture is of limited utility in the diagnosis of malaria as the organism cannot be cultured in traditional media. For bacterial infections such as salmonellosis (typhoid fever), fungal infection, and meningococcemia, blood cultures would be an appropriate diagnostic test. (Choice B) In the absence of meningeal signs (eg, neck stiffness and rash) lumbar puncture is less helpful. (Choice D) Acute viral hepatitis can cause jaundice and right upper-quadrant pain but would not result in anemia and splenomegaly. (Choice E) Stool sample for ova and parasites would be helpful for infections such as schistosomiasis, but this patient did not drink fresh water or swim during his travels. The lack of eosinophilia argues against this testing. Educational objective: Malaria should be considered in a traveler returning from an endemic area who has acute febrile illness, anemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice. Persons who have received inadequate prophylaxis are at risk. Identification of the parasite on peripheral blood smear can establish the diagnosis.

stem:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to joint pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain is primarily in the lower extremities and is not associated with joint swelling or redness. She has had no skin rashes, chest pain, or urinary symptoms but has had malaise, profound fatigue, and decreased appetite. The patient's symptoms began after she visited her family in Connecticut. She has a history of mitral valve prolapse, and her current medications include oral contraceptives and a multivitamin. The patient works as a paralegal. She does not use tobacco or illicit drugs and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis.

Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, pulse is 89/min, and respirations are 18/min. BMI is 23 kg/m2 The patient is mildly ill-appearing but in no acute distress. Dental hygiene is poor. Cardiopulmonary auscultation reveals clear lung fields and a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex that radiates to the axillae. There is tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with an enlarged spleen. No joint swelling or erythema is present, and there is no skin rash or lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 90 fL
Leukocytes: 11,000/mm3
Complement, serum:
C3: 15 mg/dL (55-120 mg/dL)
Total: 12 U/mL (37-55 U/mL)
Rheumatoid factor: 53 U/mL (<40 U/mL)

Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient with poor dentition and a history of mitral valve prolapse has low-grade fever, arthralgias, and likely mitral regurgitation (apex murmur radiating to axilla), raising concern for infective endocarditis (IE). Further evaluation with 3 sets of blood cultures and echocardiography is now required to estimate the likelihood of IE using the modified Duke criteria. Patients with suspected IE also usually receive a chest x-ray, ECG, and additional laboratory studies. Common laboratory abnormalities include normochromic/normocytic anemia, leukocytosis with left shift, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (90% of cases), decreased complement levels (C3, C4, and CH50), and positive rheumatoid factor due to circulating immune complexes. Imaging of the spine for vertebral myelitis or abdomen for splenic infarcts (as is likely in this case) is also warranted in the appropriate clinical setting. (Choice A) Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are commonly seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis. Although both syndromes can be associated with arthralgias and systemic symptoms, most patients also have ear (eg, otitis), nose (eg, rhinorrhea, sinusitis), throat (eg, hoarseness), and/or renal manifestations (eg, glomerulonephritis). Cardiac involvement would be atypical. (Choice C) Bone marrow biopsy is most commonly performed to evaluate for hematologic malignancy. Although this patient does have splenomegaly and complete blood count abnormalities, given her dental disease, mitral valve prolapse, and constellation of manifestations, she should first undergo an evaluation for IE with blood cultures and echocardiogram. Splenomegaly can sometimes be seen with IE. If the modified Duke criteria reveals a low probability of IE, she may require bone marrow biopsy for further evaluation. (Choice D) Cervical smear and culture could diagnosis Neisseria gonorrhea infection. Disseminated gonococcus can cause a triad of symptoms (ie, tenosynovitis, pustular skin lesions, polyarthralgias) or purulent arthritis without skin lesions. This patient with polyarthritis has a cardiac murmur, splenomegaly, and no skin lesions, making IE more likely. (Choice E) Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Although this patient visited an endemic region (the northeastern United States), Lyme carditis typically presents with atrioventricular conduction block or decreased contractility due to myopericarditis. A new cardiac murmur and splenomegaly are more suggestive of IE. Educational objective: Patients with suspected infective endocarditis require blood cultures (3 sets) and echocardiography to estimate its likelihood using the modified Duke criteria.

stem: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a cat bite. There was blood at the puncture site, which she rapidly cleaned with water. The cat demonstrated no abnormal behavior. The patient has no significant past medical history and received a tetanus booster 4 years ago. She developed hives after receiving penicillin 5 years ago but has since tolerated cephalosporins without allergic reaction. She takes no medications. She is afebrile, her vital signs are normal, and she has no rash. There is a clean-appearing puncture wound on the medial left hand with mild swelling and surrounding erythema. There is no tenderness over the surrounding bone. The wound is cleaned. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: This patient presents with a cat bite resulting in a deep puncture wound to the hand. Cat bites can be quite deep. Although cat saliva contains multiple different bacteria (eg, Streptococcus and anaerobic bacteria), Pasturella multocida is found in nearly 50% of cat bites. These infections, particularly when located on extremities, can progress to bone and/or joint infections. Antibiotic prophylaxis can reduce infection rates and is recommended for animal bite wounds near lymphatics and blood vessels, on the hand, close to joints and/or bones, requiring surgical intervention, and in immunocompromised hosts. Amoxicillin/clavulanate is preferred for prophylaxis and doxycycline/metronidazole is recommended in patients with penicillin allergy. Doxycycline or TMP-SMX-based regimens also are used to treat MRSA infections in high-risk patients. Antibiotics ineffective against P multocida include first-generation cephalosporins (cephalexin), penicillinase-resistant penicillins (dicloxacillin), and macrolides (erythromycin) (Choice A). Wounds should be irrigated with debris removal and should be left open to heal by secondary intention rather than primary closure (Choice C). Careful follow-up is warranted to assess for deeper infection that may require extended antibiotic therapy. Primary closure may be done at that time if there are no signs of infection. Nonhealing wounds will likely require surgical debridement. Patients should also receive tetanus booster if indicated and be considered for rabies vaccine. (Choice D) Tetanus immunoglobulin is recommended for patients with high-risk bites who have not been recently immunized against tetanus (<=5 years). (Choice E) Wound culture following animal bites has not been demonstrated to be clinically useful. Some organisms, including P multocida, are fastidious and difficult to grow in culture. Educational objective: Prophylactic antibiotics are warranted following a cat bite with deep injury. Antibiotic coverage should include an agent that treats Pasturella multocida. Amoxicillin/clavulanate is preferred as first-line therapy, and doxycycline/metronidazole is used in patients with penicillin allergy.

stem: A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 4-day history of shortness of breath and fever. He is a chronic injection drug user. He has a history of a rash secondary to penicillin but has been treated previously for skin abscesses with cephalexin. His temperature is 38.5 C (101.4 F). Cardiac examination reveals a faint diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. Skin examination shows needle track marks on both arms. All 4 bottles of blood cultures obtained on admission grow Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-susceptible). Intravenous cefazolin is initiated. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a 0.9 cm aortic valve vegetation with mild aortic regurgitation and normal left ventricular ejection fraction. On the third day of hospitalization, he is intermittently febrile and develops respiratory failure. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation is initiated. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral alveolar opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
choice_d: Obtain CT of the chest with contrast
explanation: This patient with aortic valve endocarditis was initially appropriately treated with intravenous antibiotics. However, his sudden clinical deterioration with respiratory failure and pulmonary edema suggests a mechanical complication of endocarditis. The most common cause of acute congestive heart failure (CHF) in patients with infective endocarditis is valvular insufficiency, either due to valve leaflet perforation or worsening regurgitation. The best next step for evaluation is a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). TEE is superior to TTE (transthoracic echocardiogram) for detecting complications such as leaflet perforation, aneurysm formation, and secondary infection of other valve structures. Refractory CHF due to mitral or aortic valvular insufficiency from an infected valve is an indication for surgery. (Choice A) Early CHF in a patient with endocarditis is not an indication of microbiologic treatment failure. Moreover, addition of gentamicin is not recommended for the treatment of native valve endocarditis as the risk of nephrotoxicity outweighs the potential benefit. (Choice B) Rifampin is used as an essential component of the antibiotic regimen for treatment of staphylococcal prosthetic valve endocarditis. However, it is not recommended for native valve endocarditis. (Choice C) Vancomycin is recommended for the treatment of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus endocarditis. However, this patient has a methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus strain and switching antibiotics is not indicated. (Choice D) A CT scan of the chest will likely reveal bilateral pulmonary edema as seen on the chest x-ray, but would not show valvular pathology and is unlikely to add additional diagnostic information. TEE is more appropriate for definitive diagnosis in this setting. Educational objective: Transesophageal echocardiogram is highly sensitive for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis and its complications; it should be obtained early in patients with suspected complications or sudden clinical deterioration.

stem: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and decreased level of consciousness. She is accompanied by her boyfriend. Throughout the morning, she became increasingly confused and eventually unarousable, prompting him to call an ambulance. He does not know of any specific medical problems but reports that the patient had abdominal surgery after a bad automobile accident. After initial evaluation, lumbar puncture is performed and empiric antibiotic therapy is started. Cerebral spinal fluid shows Gram-negative diplococci. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the best initial choice for infectious precaution measures?
explanation: Meningococcal infection should be suspected in a young patient who presents with fever, rash, decreased level of consciousness, and Gram-negative diplococci in the spinal fluid. A history of abdominal surgery and possible splenectomy also increases the risk of meningococcal disease. Droplet precautions and antibiotic chemoprophylaxis should be instituted for those in close contact with the patient (eg, family members, healthcare workers). Droplet precautions should be in effect for the first 24 hours of antimicrobial therapy and involve wearing a facemask if within 6-10 feet of the patient. Use of a higher-level respirator mask or closing the door of the patient's room is not necessary. Rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone are the recommended antibiotic chemoprophylaxis drugs for persons at risk. (Choices A, B, and D) Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted via droplets. Unlike infectious agents transmitted in an airborne mode, it usually does not spread more than 3 feet. Educational objective: For patients with meningococcal infection, droplet precautions should be in effect for the first 24 hours of antimicrobial therapy and involve wearing a facemask if within 6-10 feet of the patient. Rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone are recommended antibiotic chemoprophylaxis drugs for persons at risk.

stem: A 19-year-old man from Arizona is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to a high- grade fever, chills, and headache. He also complains of severe pain in the groin and axillary areas, which was preceded by swelling. Two days prior to this event, the patient's father was changing carpet in the patient's room and noticed a dead rat. His temperature is 39.6 C (103.3 F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. Examination shows multiple severely tender, non-fluctuant, enlarged nodules in the axillary and groin regions. The skin over these areas is edematous and erythematous. Blood cultures are obtained. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's infection?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with infection by Yersinia pestis (bubonic plague), a gram-negative coccobacillus transmitted by infected fleas. The main Yersinia pathogens include Y. pestis, Y. enterocolitica, and Y. pseudotuberculosis. Yersinia pestis causes plague, while the other two cause diarrheal illnesses. It is transmitted by infected fleas from rodents, scratches/bites from infected cats, eating contaminated food, direct handling of infected animals, and respiratory transmission from infected humans. Urban plague involves rats, which have been the major reservoir for human epidemics. Diagnosis requires high clinical suspicion in patients with travel to endemic areas (e.g., Southwestern US) or animal exposure, and unexplained fever with regional lymphadenitis. Diagnosis can be confirmed with blood cultures, fluid culture (e.g., bubo aspirate or CSF), peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain) showing rod-shaped organisms, or serologic titers. Untreated disease can lead to bacteremia, multiorgan failure, and death in nearly 75% of patients. Suspected patients should be promptly treated with tetracyclines or streptomycin. Post-exposure prophylaxis with doxycycline is recommended for contact with known cases. (Choice A) Coccidioides immitis is endemic in the Southwestern United States. Patients usually have nonspecific systemic symptoms, dry cough, pneumonia, or skin lesions in the immunocompromised. This patient's regional lymphadenitis is not usually seen in coccidiomycosis. (Choice B) Francisella tularensis (tularemia) is transmitted via contact with infected animals (e.g.. rabbits). Patients most commonly present with ulceroglandular disease with a single erythematous papular skin ulcer with central eschar, tender local lymphadenopathy, and sudden onset of systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, etc.). (Choice C) Pasteurella multocida infection results from bites or scratches from domestic pets. Patients usually present with localized cellulitis within 24 hours, regional lymphadenopathy, and sometimes bacteremia with osteomyelitis, meningitis, or endocarditis. (Choice D) Streptobacillus moniliformis commonly causes rat bite fever. Patients usually present with fever, severe myalgias, asymmetrical arthralgias, and a fine macular rash. However, it usually does not cause regional lymphadenitis. Educational objective: Yersinia pestis infection causes the highly lethal bubonic plague and presents with swollen and painful lymph nodules and sudden onset of high-grade fever. Suspected patients should be treated rapidly with tetracyclines or streptomycin. Post-exposure prophylaxis with doxycycline is recommended for contact with known cases.

A 43-year-old man with a history of active intravenous drug use comes to the emergency department with 2 weeks of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea on exertion. He admits to anorexia and a 5-kg (11- lb) weight loss over the past 3 weeks. About 2 hours ago, he felt sudden, sharp, right-sided chest pain and became acutely dyspneic. Pulse oximetry on ambulance arrival showed 80% on room air. The patient was started on 5 L O2/min with notable improvement of saturation. He has known HIV and chronic hepatitis C infections but is not receiving any therapy. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and last sniffed heroin this morning. His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 18/min. Pulse oximetry shows 94% on 4 L O2/min. Examination shows a cachectic man in mild respiratory distress. The lymph nodes are not enlarged. There is a faint systolic murmur at the left sternal border and tachycardia. Decreased breath sounds are heard on the right with clear lungs on the left. There is hyperresonance to percussion on the right side of the chest. There is no peripheral edema or skin rashes. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
Platelets: 120,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 10,000/mm3
Neutrophils: 80%
Sodium: 131 mEq/L
Potassium: 3.8 mEq/L
Chloride: 106 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 26 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen: 14 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase, serum: 472 U/L
Lactic acid, venous blood: 2.8 mg/dL

Arterial blood gas analysis shows pH of 7.48, PCO2 of 31 mm Hg, and PO2 of 71 mm Hg. Chest x-ray shows a 30% right-sided pneumothorax with bibasilar reticular opacities and a thin-walled cavitary lesion in the left upper lung field. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient with HIV likely has Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) complicated by pneumothorax. A subacute course with dyspnea, dry cough, and fever is classic for PCP. Other symptoms include chest pain, malaise, weight loss, headache, night sweats, chills, and fatigue. Of AIDS patients with PCP, 6%-7% may be asymptomatic. Lack of fever (as in this patient) does not exclude PCP, although it does make a bacterial or mycobacterial source less likely. Nearly 90% of patients have lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels >50 U/L above baseline; an LDH >450 U/L is predictive of PCP rather than another pulmonary process. Arterial blood gas analysis usually shows hypoxemia, an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient, and respiratory alkalosis. The most commonly described radiographic appearance in PCP is interstitial infiltrates (unilateral, bilateral, or diffuse), although a normal chest x-ray can be seen. Thin-walled cavitary lesions may be present. Spontaneous pneumothorax develops in approximately 5% of PCP patients. Pneumothorax is thought to develop primarily in the setting of rupture of cystic lesions that may be present in active disease or remaining from an earlier infection. (Choices A and E) Many of this patient's symptoms are also features of mycobacterial infection. However, the constellation of pneumothorax, LDH > 450 IU/L, relatively short duration of symptoms, lack of documented fevers, and thin-walled cavity on radiograph makes PCP more likely. (Choice C) Chronic necrotizing pulmonary aspergillosis is a subacute infection most commonly seen in patients with altered local defenses from pre-existing pulmonary disease or those with risk factors that alter systemic immune status. This infection is less likely given the lack of "fungus ball" appearance on chest x- ray and the likely only mild pre-existing pulmonary disease. (Choice D) Staphylococcal lung abscess can be seen in patients with septic emboli from endocarditis. This patient has a pneumothorax and not the multiple thick-walled cavities typical of septic emboli; he also has no fever or elevated white blood cell count. Educational objective: Nearly 90% of patients with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) will have lactic acid dehydrogenase levels >50 U/L above baseline; a level >450 U/L is predictive of PCP rather than another pulmonary process. The most commonly described radiographic appearance in PCP is diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Spontaneous pneumothorax develops in approximately 5% of patients.

A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with sudden-onset unremitting fevers, chills, and joint pains for the past 2 days. She describes severe, "unbearable" pain in her right shoulder, left elbow, and left knee. She has not had any nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Three days ago, the patient returned from a 2-week honeymoon in the Dominican Republic. She spent time camping and swimming in the ocean. Her husband has no symptoms. The patient's temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 114/64 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. She has no skin rash. Her lungs are clear bilaterally and there are no heart murmurs. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. Joint examination shows swelling in the left elbow and left knee without localized effusions or tenderness. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 12.6 g/dL
Hematocrit: 38%
Platelets: 180,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 3,400/mm3
Blood urea nitrogen: 14 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 1.3 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 32 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 44 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient, who recently returned from a trip to the Dominican Republic, has a classic presentation for Chikungunya fever (acquired by a bite from an infected Aedes mosquito). This includes the abrupt onset of persistent high fevers and characteristic severe polyarthralgias (seen in virtually all cases and often involving multiple joint groups). Some patients develop a rash. Lymphopenia and thrombocytopenia are common; elevated transaminases may also be seen. Serologic studies (or polymerase chain reaction testing in the first 5 days) can confirm the diagnosis. The infection is most often self-limited, although a few patients develop serious complications; rheumatologic symptoms may persist after the acute phase. (Choice B) The absence of gastrointestinal symptoms and presence of arthralgias make enteric fever (eg, typhoid fever) less likely. Many enteric fevers are transmitted through consumption of contaminated water. (Choice C) Hantavirus is transmitted by rodents and can cause hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome or hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome, typically 2-3 weeks following exposure. This patient has normal kidney function, no hemorrhage, no respiratory symptoms, and no rodent exposure history. (Choice D) Malaria would classically be accompanied by gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Fevers are typically cyclical (unlike the unremitting fevers seen in this patient), and polyarthralgias would not be as prominent. (Choice E) Meningococcemia (with or without meningitis) would more commonly manifest as progressive rash, pronounced myalgias, and rapid hemodynamic deterioration. Educational objective: Chikungunya virus disease should be considered in patients who develop fevers and severe polyarthralgias shortly after travel to an endemic area.

A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a high-grade fever and multiple painful skin nodules that began 2 days ago. The skin lesions are red and painful, and gradually developed on both arms before spreading to the chest and legs. He also notes fatigue, poor appetite, dry cough, and mild shortness of breath. One week ago, the patient was helping his father in the garden. The patient had an allogeneic bone marrow transplantation for acute leukemia 3 months ago complicated by pneumonia, catheter-associated bacteremia, and chronic gastrointestinal graft-versus-host-disease. His medications include prednisone, valganciclovir, and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. His temperature is 39.4 C (103.0 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 106/min and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows dry mucus membranes, diffuse crackles in the lung fields, and mild splenomegaly. Skin examination reveals dry skin with multiple raised, erythematous, and tender nodules on his upper extremities, lower extremities, and upper chest. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 29%
Leukocyte count: 18,000 cells/uL
Neutrophils: 98%

The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on empiric antibiotic therapy. Blood cultures are obtained and grow mold-like organisms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
explanation: This patient's presentation is most concerning for Fusarium species, which is the second most common pathogenic mold. Fusarium is found in soil and plant debris and directly invades tissue to cause destruction. Invasive disease most commonly occurs in severely immunosuppressed patients (i.e., neutropenia, lymphopenia, graft-vs-host disease, and corticosteroids), particularly those with hematologic malignancies receiving induction chemotherapy or bone marrow transplantation. Patients typically present with refractory fever (> 90%) to antibacterial and/or antifungal therapy, skin lesions (precede fungemia by approximately 5 days), and sinopulmonary infections (~75%). Diagnosis is suggested by skin biopsy (> 50% of patients) and/or positive blood cultures (~40% of patients) that usually grow a mold. Patients without a definitive skin biopsy diagnosis require tissue biopsy. Fusarium is resistant to many antifungal agents and carries a high mortality (60-80%) in immunocompromised patients, particularly those who are neutropenic or taking steroids. High-dose amphotericin B and/or voriconazole are most often used with varying degrees of success. Prevention is key with patients avoiding tap water or soil contact to areas of broken skin. (Choice A) Aspergillus fumigatus may cause pneumonia and skin lesions, but usually does not have positive blood cultures. Immunocompromised patients also tend to present more often with pulmonary complaints progressing to multi-organ failure rather than primary skin lesions. (Choice B) Candida albicans is a diploid fungus rather than a mold. Also, C. albicans typically presents in the first 60 days after organ transplantation with clusters of painless pustules on an erythematous base. (Choice D) Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that is rare in bone marrow transplant patients, but more common in patients with HIV, solid organ transplants, and in those taking anti-TNF therapy. (Choice E) Nocardia is a weakly staining gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria that forms partially acid-fast beaded branching filaments. Nocardiosis with skin disease usually presents as ulcerations, pyoderma, cellulitis, nodules, and subcutaneous abscesses. Educational objective: Fusariosis can occur in severely immunocompromised patients. Inoculation commonly occurs when breaks in the skin are exposed to tap water or soil. Patients can present with refractory fever, skin lesions, and pulmonary disease. Diagnosis is suggested by skin biopsy (> 50% of patients) and/or positive blood cultures (~40% of patients) that usually grow a mold. Treatment is with amphotericin B +/- voriconazole with varying efficacy.

A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever, chills, and severe throat pain for the last 2 days. She reports having a sore throat 1 week prior, which did not resolve with amoxicillin therapy. She takes no other medications and denies any recent travel or illicit drug use. Her temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 90/62 mm Hg, pulse is 114/min, and respirations are 18/min. There is no skin rash. Oral examination reveals moist mucus membranes, erythema involving the oropharynx, and tonsillar enlargement without exudates. The right side of her neck is swollen and tender. There are no heart murmurs. There is no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 12.6 g/dL
Platelets: 110,000/uL
Leukocyte count: 21,000 cells/uL
Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL

Chest x-ray reveals two round opacities in the right upper lung. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
explanation: This patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of septic thrombophlebitis involving the internal jugular vein (Lemierre's syndrome). Infection is usually caused by the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium necrophorum. Previously healthy young adults are most commonly affected, and present with pharyngitis or dental infection. The infection may improve spontaneously, extend to the lateral pharyngeal space, or involve the carotid sheath (e.g., internal jugular vein, internal carotid artery, vagus nerve) to produce a sepsis syndrome with a high mortality rate. The condition should be suspected in patients with a recent history of pharyngitis who develop neck pain, neck swelling, and persistent fever despite appropriate oral antibiotic therapy. Septic pulmonary emboli and other embolic phenomenon (e.g., arthritis, osteomyelitis) are common. Diagnosis is suggested by radiographic imaging showing internal jugular vein thrombophlebitis and is confirmed with blood or tissue cultures growing the causative oropharyngeal pathogen. Treatment usually involves 4 weeks of antibiotics that have anaerobic coverage, such as beta-lactams with beta-lactamase inhibitors (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam), clindamycin, or carbapenems. (Choice B) Corynebacterium diphtheria infection usually presents with a sore throat with gray and white tonsillar exudates (pseudomembrane), cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, and sometimes cutaneous ulcers. The infection can extend into the neck and respiratory tract to cause respiratory distress. However, septic emboli are not seen. (Choice C) Infectious mononucleosis usually presents as a systemic illness with fever, fatigue, sore throat with tonsillar exudates, splenomegaly, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient's lack of splenomegaly and presence of septic emboli make this diagnosis less likely. (Choice D) MRSA can cause skin infections and pneumonia, but it is a less common cause of pharyngitis. (Choice E) Mycobacterial infection can cause cervical lymphadenitis with neck swelling, but it is usually more gradual in onset without the sudden appearance of systemic symptoms as seen in this patient. Educational objective: Septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein should be suspected in patients with a recent history of pharyngitis who develop neck pain, neck swelling, persistent fever despite antibiotic therapy, and cavitary lung lesions. Infection is usually due to the anaerobic organism Fusobacterium necrophorum. Treatment involves 4 weeks of antibiotics with anaerobic coverage.

A 20-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy and confusion. He is obtunded and unable to answer questions, but his friend says the patient has had shaking chills and diarrhea since last night. He has no prior medical problems other than a nasal fracture following a bar fight 3 days ago, which was reduced and stabilized with nasal packing at another hospital. The patient takes no medications and has no known drug allergies. He lives in a dormitory and recently returned from a hiking trip in North Carolina. Temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 84/42 mm Hg, pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination shows an ill-appearing man. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive. Anterior packing is present in the left nostril. There is diffuse erythema of the mucous membranes and skin, including the palms and soles. Mild pitting edema is present in both legs. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 16.2 g/dL
Platelets: 100,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 13,800/mm3
Neutrophils: 90%
Sodium: 130 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen: 52 mg/dL
Creatinine: 2.9 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 1.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 70 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 102 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 96 U/L
Creatine kinase, serum: 680 U/L

CT scan of the head reveals no abnormalities. Venous access is established, and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate antimicrobial therapy for this patient?
explanation: This patient who had nasal packing 3 days ago now has manifestations of toxic shock syndrome (TSS). TSS is usually caused by a powerful Staphylococcus aureus exotoxin, which acts as a superantigen and results in the widespread activation of T cells, leading to a massive inflammatory response. Most cases are associated with menstrual tampons, nasal packing, or surgical/postpartum wound infections. Staphylococcal TSS is marked by rapid-onset fever (>38.9 C [102 F]), hypotension, diffuse erythroderma, desquamating rash, and multiorgan failure. Encephalopathy can occur secondary to cerebral edema. S aureus can usually be isolated from the infection source, but blood cultures are rarely (<5%) positive. Management is focused on supportive therapy, removal of the foreign material (eg, nasal packing, tampon) or surgery (eg, wound infections), and the initiation of antistaphylococcal antibiotics. Clindamycin and vancomycin are used most commonly; clindamycin is highly effective at inhibiting toxin production. Eradication of S aureus from the nares with mupirocin may be considered after recovery. TSS can also be caused by group A streptococcus, but patients typically have a painful skin infection and are less likely to develop erythroderma. (Choice A) Meningococcemia can cause rapid-onset fever, altered mental status, hypotension, and rash. However, petechial rash (not erythroderma) is the norm, and patients also frequently have myalgias, meningeal signs, and headache. Suspected cases are usually treated empirically with ceftriaxone and vancomycin. (Choice B) Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a tick-borne illness that usually begins with nonspecific systemic symptoms followed 3-5 days later by a maculopapular/petechial rash (starts on ankles/wrists and spreads centrally and to the palms/soles). Early treatment with doxycycline is required to prevent morbidity and death. (Choice C) Secondary syphilis is treated with penicillin G. Although secondary syphilis can cause a diffuse maculopapular rash, it is unlikely to cause rapid decompensation with hypotension. (Choice D) Vancomycin and cefepime would be indicated if this patient suffered a basal skull fracture during his fight and developed meningitis. Although he does have high fever and altered mental status, the presence of nasal packing, erythroderma, and multiorgan failure makes TSS more likely. Educational objective: Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS) must be considered in patients with abrupt onset of fever, hypotension, and diffuse erythroderma. Most cases occur in the setting of menstrual tampons, nasal packing, or surgical/postpartum wound infections. Treatment involves supportive care, removing the foreign material (or surgery), and broad-spectrum antistaphylococcal antibiotics (eg, clindamycin and vancomycin).

stem: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to progressive lethargy over the last 24 hours. Before going to bed, he had a fever, chills, headache, and neck pain and was "feeling tired." His wife had difficulty waking him up this morning. The patient has had no sick contacts, recent travel, flu- like symptoms, or skin rashes. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and ischemic stroke with a complete recovery of neurologic deficits. The patient takes aspirin, metformin, chlorthalidone, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is a retired school teacher and has no history of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. Temperature is 39.1 C (102.3 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. The patient is obtunded and does not follow commands but is able to localize to pain in the upper extremities and withdraw the lower extremities to noxious stimuli. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Fingerstick glucose level is 190 mg/dL. Blood cultures are drawn. Which of the following is the best next step in immediate management of this patient?
choice_b: Brain MRI with and without contrast
explanation: This patient has high fever, neck pain, and altered mental status, the 3 classic manifestations of acute bacterial meningitis. Most cases are caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, but Neisseria meningitis, group B streptococci, Haemophilus influenzae, and Listeria monocytogenes (in patients age >50) are also frequently isolated. Blood cultures and lumbar puncture (LP) are required for definitive diagnosis. Blood cultures successfully identify the underlying pathogen in 50%-90% of cases and should always be drawn prior to antimicrobials to maximize their yield. The timing of LP is more nuanced as patients with any of the following require a preceding noncontrast head CT scan: Altered mental status (as in this patient); Immunocompromised state; History of central nervous system disease; New-onset seizure; Papilledema; Focal neurologic deficit. Head CT scan often results in treatment delays of up to 6 hours, which can increase the risk of death and neurologic sequelae. As such, patients with suspected bacterial meningitis who require a head CT scan prior to LP should first receive empiric treatment with antibiotics and adjuvant dexamethasone (Choices D and E). Antimicrobial treatment prior to LP can reduce the yield of cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture, but most pathogens can still be successfully cultivated for 4-10 hours after antibiotic initiation. Patients who do not require a head CT scan prior to LP should undergo LP before the administration of antimicrobials. Most patients with suspected bacterial meningitis are also treated with empiric acyclovir to cover for possible herpes simplex encephalitis. (Choice A) Bedside electroencephalogram monitoring is often used to evaluate for nonconvulsive status epilepticus, which can occur in the setting of an infectious encephalopathy and lead to mental status changes. However, this patient should first receive empiric antibiotics; electroencephalogram can be considered if there is no mental status improvement. (Choice B) Brain MRI takes longer to perform than a head CT scan. Therefore, urgent noncontrast head CT scan is preferred in patients with acute mental status changes to rule out space-occupying lesions. Educational objective: Patients with suspected acute bacterial meningitis require early treatment with empiric antibiotics and dexamethasone to limit neurologic sequelae and death. Those who need a head CT scan (eg, altered mental state, focal neurologic deficit, immunocompromised state, new-onset seizure, papilledema, history of central nervous system disease) prior to lumbar puncture should first receive blood cultures, antibiotics, and dexamethasone. Patients who do not require a head CT scan should receive blood cultures and lumbar puncture prior to treatment.

stem: A 64-year-old man with a history of benign prostate hyperplasia comes to the office with 2 days of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and suprapubic discomfort. The patient had similar symptoms 3 months ago and was treated with antibiotics. This resolved his urinary symptoms, but he developed Clostridium difficile colitis, which necessitated oral vancomycin therapy. The patient currently has no gastrointestinal symptoms. His other medical problems include hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.6 C (99.8 F), blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min. The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender with normal bowel sounds. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. The prostate is moderately enlarged, smooth, and nontender. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite. His previous urine culture had grown Escherichia coli, which was sensitive to all tested antibiotics. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial therapy for this patient given his history of C difficile colitis?
explanation: This patient with a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy likely has complicated cystitis; in the outpatient setting, complicated cystitis is usually managed with an oral fluoroquinolone. However, fluoroquinolones are associated with a high risk of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and should generally be avoided in those with a history of CDAD when an alternate, lower-risk antibiotic is available (Choice C). The patient's recent episode of cystitis was due to pansensitive Escherichia coli; therefore, treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole would likely provide adequate coverage while also conferring a low risk of CDAD. (Choice A) This patient has normal vital signs and no vomiting; he can be treated in the outpatient setting with oral antibiotics. In addition, broad-spectrum cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone are associated with a high risk of C difficile relapse. (Choice B) Broad-spectrum penicillins such as amoxicillin-clavulanic acid are highly associated with CDAD and should be avoided when possible in patients who have had recent CDAD infections. Although amoxicillin-clavulanic acid can be used to treat cystitis, it is more commonly administered for respiratory infections. (Choice D) Nitrofurantoin should not be used for men with cystitis as it does not reach reliable tissue concentrations and is less effective than other therapies if occult prostatitis is present. Educational objective: Patients with a history of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) should have careful antibiotic stewardship. Fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, and broad-spectrum penicillins/cephalosporins are associated with high rates of CDAD; therefore, alternate antibiotics with a lower risk of CDAD should be used when possible.

A 61-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is evaluated for persistent fever in the cardiac intensive care unit. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) six days ago. He has been receiving mechanical ventilation, and is unable to be weaned off the ventilator. Four days after his surgery, he developed fever, increased oxygen requirements, and abundant secretions from the endotracheal tube. He was started on intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam. His current temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min and oxygen saturation is 90% on 60% FiO2 and 5 mm Hg of PEEP. Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocyte count: 19,800 cells/uL
Neutrophils: 88%
Eosinophils: 3%
Lymphocytes: 7%
Monocytes: 2%

Chest x-ray shows a dense right lower lobe infiltrate. Blood cultures sent two days ago return negative. Which of the following is the best additional therapy for this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation (fever, increased purulent respiratory secretions, and new right lower lobe infiltrate) is consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), defined as pneumonia occurring 48-72 hours after endotracheal intubation. Intubated patients are at higher risk for pneumonia due to aspiration of organisms colonizing the oropharyngeal tract, including hospital-acquired organisms. Common VAP organisms include methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), P. aeruginosa, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and Acinetobacter. Current guidelines recommend coverage for the above organisms, especially MRSA (in areas of high incidence), with vancomycin or linezolid (both equally efficacious). However, linezolid is preferred in hospitals where a major portion of MRSA isolates have a vancomycin minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) >= 2 mcg/mL. This patient was started on intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam, which covers both MSSA and gram-negative pathogens well. However, he is not clinically improving and may have MRSA, thus he requires the addition of linezolid to his regimen. (Choice A) Azithromycin covers many gram-positive, atypical, and some gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Legionella). However, it is not effective against MRSA. (Choice B) Daptomycin is bactericidal with activity against MRSA, and is approved for treating skin and soft tissue infections and bacteremia with or without endocarditis. However, pulmonary surfactant inhibits the drug, making it less effective for treating pneumonia. (Choice D) Tigecycline is a tetracycline derivative approved for skin and soft tissue infections (including MRSA) and intraabdominal infections not caused by MRSA. However, its use is associated with increased mortality in patients with VAP. (Choice E) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can treat MRSA skin and soft tissue infections, but there is no published data regarding its efficacy for pneumonia or other invasive MRSA infections. Educational objective: Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) typically presents with fever, purulent secretions, and hypoxia in ventilated patients 48-72 hours after intubation. Common organisms include MRSA, MSSA, and gram- negative organisms (e.g., Pseudomonas). Vancomycin and linezolid are appropriate first-line agents for treating MRSA pneumonia.

stem: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever, chills, and drenching sweats. He has had no sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, or dysuria. The patient has a history of Crohn disease and recently underwent abdominal surgery to remove a bowel stricture. The postoperative course was complicated by an enterocutaneous fistula, which has been treated over the past 6 weeks with antitumor necrosis factor therapy. This treatment has reduced the amount of drainage from the fistula. He has had no recent abdominal pain or diarrhea. The patient takes nothing by mouth and receives daily total parenteral nutrition. He has no other medical problems and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 18/min The patient is ill-appearing and diaphoretic. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and nontender with clear discharge from the infraumbilical fistula site. The right upper arm peripherally inserted central catheter site has no erythema or tenderness. Leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Chest x-ray reveals no infiltrates. Urinalysis is normal. Blood cultures are obtained, and empiric broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are initiated. Within the next 24 hours, both sets of blood cultures grow budding yeast. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Change the catheter via guidewire and begin intravenous fluconazole
choice_b: Keep the catheter and begin intravenous liposomal amphotericin B
choice_c: Remove the catheter and await species identification of the yeast
choice_d: Remove the catheter and begin intravenous caspofungin
choice_e: Repeat blood cultures and continue broad-spectrum antibiotics
explanation: This patient with budding yeasts on blood cultures likely has candidemia, a common hospital-acquired infection that is frequently linked to central venous catheters, total parenteral nutrition, and immunocompromised states (eg, neutropenia). Clinical manifestations are myriad and range from mild fever to full-blown sepsis with or without end-organ involvement (eg, chorioretinitis, endocarditis, meningitis). Blood cultures are the gold standard for diagnosis, but sensitivity is low (~50%) so serum markers (eg, beta-D-glucan) and/or biopsy with histology are sometimes required. The cornerstone of treatment for candidemia is: Central venous catheter removal - catheter removal speeds clearance of candidemia and reduces mortality rates; it should be performed when feasible (eg, alternate access is available); Empiric antifungal treatment - echinocandins such as caspofungin are first-line therapy due to excellent coverage against the most common infective species including Candida albicans, C glabrata, C tropicalis, C parapsilosis, and C krusei. All patients with candidemia should also undergo ophthalmologic examination to evaluate for endophthalmitis. (Choice A) Although fluconazole has excellent efficacy against C albicans, it does not adequately cover many strains of C glabrata and C krusei. As such, azoles are not generally used as a first-line empiric therapy for candidemia. Changing the catheter via guidewire increases the risk of septic emboli and may result in inoculation of the new catheter. (Choice B) The catheter should be removed if possible. Liposomal amphotericin B is considered a second-line agent for candidemia due to a greater risk of side effects (when compared to echinocandins). (Choice C) Catheter removal without antifungal treatment is associated with high mortality rates. Treatment should not be delayed for species and susceptibility results; this patient requires the prompt initiation of antifungal therapy. (Choice E) Gram stain evidence of budding yeasts on blood cultures should never be considered a contaminant. There is no need to repeat blood cultures; antifungal treatment should be initiated. Educational objective: Candidemia is a common hospital-acquired infection and usually occurs in the setting of a central venous catheter, total parenteral nutrition, and/or an immunocompromised state (eg, neutropenia). The cornerstone of treatment is catheter removal and empiric antifungal therapy with an echinocandin (eg, caspofungin). Candida in blood cultures should never be considered a contaminant.

stem: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician after recently returning from a trip to Bangladesh. He reports 1 week of fever and left lower-quadrant abdominal pain. His medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. His current medications include metformin and lisinopril. His temperature is 103° F (39.4 C), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. Examination shows an uncomfortable-appearing man in no acute distress. There is an erythematous, macular, patchy rash across his lower abdomen. The abdomen is soft with left lower- quadrant tenderness. There is no rebound tenderness or involuntary guarding. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL Hematocrit 35% Platelets 230,000/ μL Leukocytes 13,400/ μL Sodium 140 mEq/L Potassium 4.2 mEq/L Chloride 114 mEq/L Bicarbonate 20 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL Total protein 5.5 g/dL Albumin 3.4 g/dL Total Bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL Direct Bilirubin 0.1 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 320 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 212 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 314 U/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is suggestive of typhoid fever, which is caused by Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi and is commonly seen in the developing world. Patients typically present with fever and bacteremia within 5-20 days after ingestion of contaminated food or water. They can also present later with abdominal pain and a characteristic erythematous, macular rash. Laboratory studies may show a normal platelet count, leukopenia or leukocytosis, and abnormal liver function tests. The most serious stage of typhoid fever is intestinal perforation (due to hyperproliferation of Peyer's patches), which can lead to peritonitis, bacteremia, septic shock, and death. Diagnosis is made by culture, and S typhi and S paratyphi can be isolated from stool, urine, and intestinal contents. However, bone marrow is the most sensitive (> 90%), with a higher yield of organisms than other body fluids. Blood cultures are usually performed out of convenience, but the sensitivity in isolating S typhi or S paratyphi ranges from 40%-80%. Bone marrow cultures can be particularly useful as they remain positive in a high percentage of patients who received antibiotics for several days prior to culture. (Choice A) Classic dengue fever presents with fever lasting 5-7 days, headache, retro-orbital pain, rash, and body aches ("breakbone fever"). Laboratory findings include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevations in serum aspartate aminotransferase levels. (Choice B) Leptospirosis presents with abrupt onset of fever, myalgias, headache, and abdominal pain. An important clinical feature is conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva without inflammatory exudates), which is not present in most other infectious diseases. (Choice C) Patients with malaria present from an endemic region with nonspecific symptoms such as fever that waxes and wanes, chills, headache, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. They usually have splenomegaly, and initial laboratory data show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hyperbilirubinemia. Rash is not a common clinical feature of malaria. (Choice E) Patients with acute viral hepatitis usually present with fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. Common laboratory abnormalities include marked elevations in serum aminotransferases (> 1000 U/L and alanine aminotransferase > aspartate aminotransferase), total and direct bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels. Educational objective: Typhoid fever usually presents in patients with recent travel to an endemic region with fever, bacteremia, and relative bradycardia. Patients later develop abdominal pain and a macular rash. Bone marrow culture is the most sensitive method for isolating the causative organism.

stem: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for ear pain and decreased hearing. Eight days ago, she developed rhinorrhea and a mild sore throat. Three days later, she had decreased hearing and pain in her right ear. The patient went to an urgent care clinic and was prescribed amoxicillin, which she has taken since. Despite the amoxicillin, she continues to have ear pain and diminished hearing. She has no ear drainage, fever, chills, or headache. She is in good health and her only medication is birth control pills. Vital signs are normal. There is no nystagmus. Otoscopic examination shows a cloudy, red, bulging tympanic membrane. Hearing is diminished in her right ear. A tuning fork placed in the center of her head lateralizes to the right. There is no posterior ear pain. There is no pharyngeal abnormality on examination. Her neck is supple, and gait and balance appear normal. All cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
explanation: This patient has acute otitis media. An allergic rhinitis or upper respiratory illness commonly precedes the onset of otitis media. Eustachian tube dysfunction or occlusion from inflammation is the primary factor in the pathogenesis. Blockage of the Eustachian tube causes fluid accumulation in middle ear, with subsequent bacterial growth. The 3 most common organisms are Streptococcus pneumoniae, followed by nontypeable Hemophilus influenzae and Moraxella catarrhalis. Patients usually complain of severe ear pain and hearing loss. Fever may not be present. An otoscopic examination may show redness, opacification, air-fluid level, and bulging of the tympanic membrane. Use of a pneumatic otoscope would reveal poor movability of the tympanic membrane when pneumatic pressure is applied. A tuning fork examination can add to the diagnosis by revealing conductive hearing loss. In an immunocompetent host with no previous history of otitis media, amoxicillin is considered first-line treatment. If symptoms do not improve within 48-72 hours, the patient should be re-examined for a possible new area of infection or inadequate therapy. In cases of antibiotic failure, amoxicillin-clavulanate is the next best therapy to cover beta-lactamase-producing H influenzae. For patients allergic to penicillin, alternatives to amoxicillin therapy are second-generation (eg, cefuroxime) or third-generation (eg, cefdinir) cephalosporins. In patients allergic to beta-lactam antibiotics, a macrolide (eg, azithromycin) can be used. (Choice C) A CT scan is usually done in patients who do not respond and/or develop complications despite being on an adequate antibiotic regimen. Common complications include mastoiditis, brain abscess, and lateral sinus thrombosis (need an MRI). This patient has no posterior ear pain, fever, or headache that would suggest extension of an infection. (Choice D) Myringotomy is used to aid middle ear drainage for individuals with unresolved chronic otitis media with effusion or mastoiditis. Neither is present in this patient. (Choice E) Nasopharyngoscopy can be considered in patients with recurrent otitis media (> 2 episodes in a 6-month period) to evaluate for other possible causes of Eustachian tube or nasopharyngeal obstruction (eg, malignancy). Educational objective: Adult otitis media is a clinical diagnosis based on the history of ear pain and conductive hearing loss as well as otoscopic findings of erythema, opacification, bulging, or air-fluid level of the tympanic membrane. Although amoxicillin is first-line antibiotic therapy, amoxicillin-clavulanate is a better choice if otitis media is unresolved in 48-72 hours.

stem: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent swelling over the left mandible for the last 3 months. The swelling initially responded to antibiotics prescribed to him 2 months ago; however, it subsequently returned. His other medical problems include a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His medications include metformin, glyburide, and lisinopril. He denies tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. His temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and respirations are 12/min. Eye examination reveals intact ocular movements. There is no nasal discharge or sinus tenderness. Palpation over the jaw reveals a 4 cm mass extending from the mandible that is raised, non-tender, and firm. There is a sinus tract extending to the skin with purulent and blood-tinged drainage. No erythema or fluctuance is noted. Examination of the oral cavity shows poor dentition with gingivitis, but no open lesions. There is neither anterior nor posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL Hematocrit 35% Platelets 190,000 cells/ μL Leukocyte count 8,300 cells/μL Sodium 140 mEq/L Potassium 4.2 mEq/L Chloride 114 mEq/L Bicarbonate 20 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this patient's condition?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with likely cervicofacial actinomycosis, which is most commonly seen in the mandibular region. Actinomyces is an anaerobic, gram-positive, and filamentous branching bacteria that colonizes the oral cavity. Patients with poor oral hygiene are more likely to develop infection. Patients typically present with a slowly growing, non-tender, and indurated mass that can form abscesses, fistulas, or draining sinus tracts. The organisms also form characteristic sulfur granules in the infected tissue and extend locally through tissue planes instead of lymphangitic or hematologic spread. Actinomycosis can mimic other conditions, such as malignancy or granulomatous disease (e.g., TB, sarcoid). Diagnosis is confirmed by tissue culture, but Actinomyces are fastidious organisms that can take up to 3 weeks to grow in culture. Intravenous penicillin for 4-6 weeks is preferred initially, followed by 6 to 12 months of oral penicillin. For patients with penicillin allergy, clindamycin is a reasonable alternative. Surgical excision may be required for more severe cases. (Choice A) Chemotherapy would treat malignancies (e.g., lymphoma) that can mimic this patient's presentation. However, malignant lesions typically do not decrease and then increase in size or form sinus tracts. (Choice B) Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with activity against gram-negative infections, some gram- positive infections (e.g., streptococci), and drug-resistant tuberculosis. Although TB causes cervical lymphadenitis, it does not typically form sinus tracts as seen in this patient. (Choice C) Metronidazole is effective for many anaerobic and parasitic infections, but is not effective for actinomycosis. This patient's sinus tracts in the mandible region are more consistent with actinomycosis. (Choice E) Prednisone is used to treat a variety of autoimmune conditions and malignancy, but is not effective for actinomycosis. This patient's lack of other systemic symptoms makes autoimmune disease less likely. Educational objective: Cervicofacial actinomycosis most commonly presents in the mandibular region as a slowly growing, non- tender mass with characteristic sulfur granules. The infection can extend through tissue planes and form abscesses, fistulas, and draining sinus tracts. Diagnosis is confirmed by culture, and penicillin for 6-12 months is the preferred therapy.

stem: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician for acute onset of a sore throat that has gotten progressively worse during the day. He is also experiencing some mild myalgias. For the past 2 days, he has had subjective fevers and a nonproductive cough. He does not have chills or fatigue. The patient has not been exposed to a similar illness and has no HIV risk factors. He has no significant past medical history, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 16/min. Oropharyngeal examination shows slightly enlarged tonsils with grayish-white exudates. There are a few palpable, bilateral, small, and slightly tender anterior cervical nodes. Auscultation of the heart and lungs is normal. The abdomen is soft, and there is no hepatosplenomegaly. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has acute pharyngitis and fulfills 3 of 4 Centor criteria (he does not fulfill the criterion of "absence of cough" given that he has a nonproductive cough). The most appropriate next step is to obtain a rapid antigen test to exclude group A streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis as untreated patients are at risk for developing complications (eg, rheumatic fever, acute glomerulonephritis, peritonsillar abscess). The Centor criteria (tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, fever by history, and absence of cough) help determine the likelihood of GAS pharyngitis and guide further workup and treatment. Patients with 0-1 criteria do not require further work up or treatment (high negative predictive value). Patients with >=2 criteria should be evaluated with a rapid streptococcal antigen test (RSAT), which has high specificity. Some clinicians will treat GAS pharyngitis empirically if all 4 criteria are met. Guidelines may use different cutoffs, but the presence of 3 criteria (as in this patient) generally warrants testing. (Choice A) Antibiotics are indicated in patients with a positive RSAT or those who fulfill 4 Centor criteria. Oral penicillin V and amoxicillin are common first-line agents due to their modest cost, narrow spectrum, and tolerability. First-generation cephalosporins (eg, cephalexin) are an alternate therapy if treatment fails. Macrolides (eg, erythromycin) are used for penicillin-allergic patients. (Choice B) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are appropriate for symptomatic relief of pain associated with nonspecific pharyngitis, but this patient should first be evaluated with an RSAT. (Choice C) Infectious mononucleosis (IM) can present in a similar fashion, but it is more common in patients age 15-24. Other signs and symptoms that are commonly seen with IM but are absent in this patient include fatigue (90%-100%), posterior lymphadenopathy (100%), and splenomegaly (60%). (Choice E) Although throat culture has high sensitivity and specificity in identifying GAS infection, the delay in obtaining results often limits its use in the acute setting. Throat culture can be considered in patients who have a negative RSAT result yet in whom the suspicion for GAS infection is still high (eg, 4 positive Centor criteria with negative RSAT). Educational objective: The Centor criteria (tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, fever by history, and absence of cough) are widely used to determine the likelihood of group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Patients with >=2 criteria should have a rapid streptococcal antigen test and receive therapy with oral penicillin or amoxicillin if test results are positive.

stem: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for consultation. The patient has a history of recurrent genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 2 infections but has no symptoms at present. She has 3 or 4 symptomatic episodes a year. The patient has no other sexually transmitted infections or medical problems and takes no medications. She has a new male sexual partner who is HSV-seronegative. Which of the following is the most effective strategy for decreasing this patient's risk of transmitting HSV to her partner?
choice_a: Abstinence for 2 weeks after an outbreak
choice_d: Condom use during prodromes and outbreaks
choice_e: Prompt antiviral treatment of the outbreaks
explanation: Recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection is common, particularly in patients with HSV-2. Partner transmission can occur in HSV-discordant couples due to asymptomatic viral shedding and symptomatic shedding during the prodromal period and active outbreaks. Multiple prevention strategies are available for discordant couples and have varying degrees of effectiveness. Patients with a history of HSV that was not confirmed by diagnostic testing (eg, viral culture) require serologic testing to determine infection status and type. It is also recommended that their sexual partners undergo evaluation to determine susceptibility.
