The patient has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease for which he receives hemodialysis 3 times a week at a dialysis center. He was hospitalized 3 months ago for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia attributed to a hemodialysis catheter that was then removed. He received pneumococcal and influenza vaccines during that admission. He is allergic to intravenous vancomycin. His temperature is 38.6 C (101.5F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 104/min and regular. He appears uncomfortable and is coughing persistently. Lung examination reveals coarse crackles at the right lung base. Heart sounds are normal with no murmur. Abdomen is soft and nontender. He has no skin rash. The patient's leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3. Chest x-ray reveals an infiltrate in the right lower lung, which is new compared to the x-ray taken 4 months earlier. Appropriate cultures have been obtained. Which of the following is the best initial antibiotic regimen for this patient?
explanation: This patient with pneumonia (fever, cough, and a new right lung infiltrate) has risk factors for resistant organisms and requires appropriate coverage: He has a known history of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia and may be colonized with this organism. He has risk factors for pneumonia due to gram-negative organisms (eg, Pseudomonas). These risk factors include: prior antibiotic therapy, recent hospitalization, multiple medical comorbidities (eg, diabetes, alcohol use disorder), immunosuppression, possible aspiration, and pulmonary comorbidities (eg, bronchiectasis). His age (>65), medical comoborbidites, and recent hospitalization also place him at risk for drug- resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae. Other risk factors include immunosuppression, exposure to children in a daycare center, and recent beta-lactam, macrolide, or fluoroquinolone therapy. Given the patient's allergy to vancomycin, linezolid (for coverage of MRSA) and cefepime (for coverage of Pseudomonas and other potentially resistant organisms) would be appropriate. (Choice A) Ceftriaxone and azithromycin are usually appropriate for community-acquired pneumonia therapy but do not have MRSA or Pseudomonas coverage. (Choices C and D) Although daptomycin has activity against MRSA, it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and should not be used in the treatment of MRSA pneumonia. (Choice E) Meropenem monotherapy would not provide adequate MRSA coverage. Educational objective: For patients with pneumonia who are at risk for Pseudomonas or other resistant pathogens, empiric antibiotic therapy should include an antipseudomonal penicillin/cephalosporin or a carbapenem. In patients with risk factors for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, either vancomycin or linezolid should be added. Daptomycin should not be used for pneumonia treatment due to its lack of activity in the lung.

stem: A 35-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with HIV comes to the office for evaluation after moving to New York City from Tucson, Arizona. She began taking highly active antiretroviral therapy 9 months ago and has been compliant with the regimen. She also takes trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole for Pneumocystis pneumonia prophylaxis. The patient reports no symptoms except for occasional nausea. Her CD4 count 3 months ago was 210/mm3. She also has a history of asthma, which is stable with inhaled beclomethasone therapy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 10.8 g/dL Leukocytes 7,500/mm3 CD4 count 270/mm3. The patient's viral load is undetectable. Chest x-ray shows no acute disease. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Azithromycin for Mycobacterium avium complex prophylaxis
choice_c: No changes are needed in her medication regimen
explanation: Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP) is a common AIDS-defining illness and is a major cause of death in patients with untreated AIDS. Prior to the use of antiretroviral therapy (ART), 70%-80% of patients with AIDS developed PCP, and approximately one-third of these individuals died from the condition. The vast majority of cases occur in patients with CD4 counts <200/mm3. Chemoprophylaxis against PCP is recommended for all patients with HIV who have CD4 counts <200/mm3. Chemoprophylaxis should also be considered in those with higher CD4 counts who develop oropharyngeal candidiasis (indicating susceptibility to opportunistic infections) or have low CD4 count percentage (<14%). Once-daily, double-strength, oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the preferred agent. Alternate medications include dapsone, pentamidine, and clindamycin/primaquine. Prophylaxis can be discontinued when ART improves CD4 counts to >200/mm3 for >3 months, as in this patient. Cessation reduces the risk of drug toxicity/interactions and of developing drug-resistant organisms. (Choice A) Azithromycin prophylaxis against Mycobacterium avium complex is recommended for patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <50/mm3. (Choice B) Primary chemoprophylaxis against coccidiomycosis is not recommended for HIV-positive patients. However, patients who live in or travel to endemic regions can be screened for exposure with twice-annual serologic testing. Those who become seropositive and have CD4 counts <250/mm3 are generally given fluconazole prophylaxis if no disease manifestations are present. (Choice D) Beclomethasone has stabilized this patient's asthma, and stopping the drug would likely worsen her condition. This drug has minimal interactions with ART and TMP-SMX. Educational objective: Prophylaxis for Pneumocystis pneumonia is recommended for patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <200/mm3. Prophylaxis can be safely discontinued in patients on antiretroviral therapy who have CD4 counts >200/mm3 for >3 months.

stem: A 44-year-old man with HIV infection is evaluated for persistent fevers, progressive generalized fatigue, poor appetite, and marked weight loss over the last 2 months. He has no chest pain or shortness of breath. He has been noncompliant with antiretroviral therapy, and his last CD4 count 6 months ago was 90/μL. His temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 91/53 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 21/min. Examination shows a pale conjunctiva and dry mucous membranes. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 7.8 g/dL Platelets 70,000/μL Leukocytes 3,200/μL Neutrophils 70% Lymphocytes 15% Monocytes 12% A CT scan of the chest and abdomen reveals lucencies in the skeleton and bulky mediastinal and abdominal lymphadenopathy. Bone marrow biopsy in this patient would most likely show which of the following?
explanation: With this patient's poorly controlled HIV status, marked body cavity lymphadenopathy, and bone lucency, the most likely underlying cause is non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). Around 4% of HIV patients have lymphoma at the time of diagnosis with the same percentage developing lymphoma during their disease course. Factors that contribute to the incidence include direct effects of HIV, immunosuppressive state, co- infection with other oncogenic viruses (eg, Epstein-Barr), and environmental oncogenic stimuli. HAART prevents severe immunosuppression, which in turn helps to decrease the incidence of NHL. Patients with NHL tend to present with B symptoms (fever, weight loss, and night sweats), extranodal disease, and involvement of unusual locations (eg, body cavity, rectum, and soft tissue). Rarely, they may present with fever of unknown origin. Diffuse large-cell NHL and Burkitt lymphoma are the most common AIDS-related lymphomas. (Choice A) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is not associated with HIV infection and the blood count differential shows predominantly mature-appearing lymphocytes. (Choice B) Fungal infections such as blastomycosis and histoplasmosis can involve bone. However, this patient's bulky lymphadenopathy is more suggestive of a lymphoma. (Choice C) Kaposi sarcoma usually presents with skin lesions (purplish, reddish blue, or dark brown/black) on the lower extremities, often associated with lymphedema. Lymph node involvement occurs infrequently. (Choice D) Although myeloma can cause bone lesions, it does not cause bulky lymphadenopathy and severe B symptoms. Educational objective: AIDS-related lymphomas are common in patients with advanced HIV, a low CD4 count (<100/μL), high HIV viral load, and a prior diagnosis of AIDS. Patients with non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) tend to present with B symptoms, extranodal disease, and involvement of unusual locations. Diffuse large-cell NHL and Burkitt lymphoma are the most common AIDS-related lymphomas.

stem: A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and severe osteoarthritis underwent a right total knee arthroplasty 3 months earlier. He comes to his primary care physician with persistent pain and swelling of the right knee. The patient has pain with activity and at rest, with the most significant pain associated with weight bearing. He has no fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. He goes to rehabilitation but his participation has been limited over the past week due to persistent pain. His temperature is 37.1 C (98.7F), blood pressure is 114/74 mm Hg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination shows a moderately swollen right knee with decreased range of motion. The surgical scar is intact without surrounding erythema. Examination of the left knee is within normal limits. An x-ray of the knee reveals an intact prosthesis. Laboratory tests, including complete blood count, electrolyte panel, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, have been ordered. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's condition?
choice_c: Magnetic resonance imaging scan of the right knee
explanation: This patient's increased knee pain and swelling 3 months after arthroplasty is concerning for either aseptic mechanical complication of the prosthesis or early-onset prosthetic joint infection (PJI). Mechanical complications typically present with pain associated with weight bearing or activity. PJI often presents with persistent pain and other localized or systemic symptoms of infection (eg, joint effusion, wound drainage, fever, erythema, induration, edema). PJI can present as early (< 3 months), delayed (3-12 months), or late onset (> 12 months) after surgery. Although plain films can be helpful in establishing the diagnosis of PJI, the sensitivity and specificity of x- ray findings are limited. The absence of x-ray findings should not deter further consideration of PJI in the appropriate setting. Diagnostic arthrocentesis should be performed in patients with suspected PJI unless open surgical drainage is anticipated or an obvious sign of infection, such as a sinus tract, is present. Synovial fluid analysis should include a cell count and differential and Gram stain and culture for aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein can be useful adjunctive tests in establishing the diagnosis. Blood cultures should also be performed. Early-onset PJI usually improves with surgical debridement followed by prolonged antibiotics. Delayed and late onset may also require prosthesis removal if debridement shows an infected prosthesis. (Choice B) Unless there are clear signs of sepsis, the use of antibiotics should follow arthrocentesis to maximize the yield of synovial fluid culture and direct antibiotic therapy. This patient appears clinically stable and should first undergo arthrocentesis. (Choice C) MRI can be done only in patients with titanium or tantalum prostheses but is still not as sensitive as arthrocentesis. (Choice D) Naproxen with close follow-up is indicated for symptomatic relief in noninfectious causes of joint pain (eg, bursitis). Although naproxen may also help this patient's symptoms, he should first undergo arthrocentesis to evaluate for PJI. (Choice E) Technetium 99m colloid bone scan is nonspecific and may show high false-positive results in the early months after prosthetic joint implantation due to periprosthetic bone remodeling. Educational objective: Prosthetic joint infection should be considered in patients with increasing pain after joint replacement. Arthrocentesis establishes the diagnosis. Treatment involves surgical debridement (or removal in delayed or late-onset cases) followed by a prolonged course of intravenous antibiotics.

stem: A 35-year-old man underwent PPD/TST (tuberculin skin test) testing one week ago. The TST showed 20 mm of erythema and 2 mm induration at the inoculation site. He complains of an occasional dry cough in the mornings but denies fever, chills, weight changes, or night sweats. His medical problems include obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, and pravastatin. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. The patient works as an ambulance transport associate at a group home for mentally challenged children, and he occasionally spends time with the same kids supervising various recreational activities. He was born in Haiti and moved to the United States at age 5 with his family. He was tested for HIV with negative results at an employee health screening last year. His vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. The patient's routine blood work during his annual physical last year was within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
choice_d: Three months of isoniazid plus rifapentine
explanation: This asymptomatic patient presents with a PPD/TST showing only 2 mm induration and 20 mm of erythema. The induration (not erythema) is used to assess reaction, and a >= 10 mm increase within a 2- year period is considered a positive test. The significance of overall induration size depends on patient risk factors (summarized in the table). This patient has no obvious TB risk factors, but he is in a higher risk population (diabetes). However, his TST is <5 mm induration and is not considered significant. As a result, he needs no further treatment or evaluation for latent TB at this time. Patients with a positive TST should undergo chest x-ray to evaluate for active pulmonary disease (Choice A). Patients with abnormal radiographic findings should be treated with an appropriate regimen and monitoring of cultures. Patients with a normal chest x-ray can be treated for latent TB (e.g., 3 months of INH plus rifapentine or 6-9 months of INH with vitamin B6 with monitoring of liver function tests (Choice D). (Choice C) Interferon gamma release assays (IGRAs) are not affected by Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination status. Quantiferon-TB test (QFT) is one type of IGRA and is preferred in patients with a history of BCG vaccination in whom there is difficulty in interpreting TST results. Educational objective: PPD/TST assesses for latent TB and a positive reaction is based on induration (rather than erythema) and patient risk factors. A positive test requires chest x-ray to rule out active infection. Patients with a negative chest x-ray should be treated with an appropriate regimen in addition to laboratory monitoring.

stem: A 34-year-old immigrant from Brazil comes to the physician with 2 months of palpitations accompanied by lightheadedness. He also complains of mild shortness of breath. The patient suffers from moderate, persistent asthma and takes daily inhaled glucocorticoid and salmeterol. He received "most of the childhood immunizations." He has no family history of heart disease or sudden cardiac death. The patient's blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg and pulse is 82/min. Estimated jugular venous pressure is normal. The apical impulse is displaced to the left. A soft 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the apex. Lungs are clear on auscultation. There is no organomegaly, skin rash, or peripheral edema. Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with right bundle branch block. Echocardiogram shows a left ventricular apical aneurysm and left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronary arteries. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
explanation: This patient has the classic clinical presentation of chronic Chagas cardiomyopathy, which is caused by a protozoan infection from Trypanosoma cruzi. The natural history of Chagas disease has 3 distinct phases. The first is an acute phase of mild, nonspecific symptoms with fever or myalgias, followed by an indeterminate phase with serologic or parasitic evidence of T cruzi infection in the absence of symptoms or signs of infection. The final phase is chronic Chagas cardiomyopathy. Chronic Chagas cardiomyopathy is the leading cause of dilated cardiomyopathy in Central and South America. Patients can remain asymptomatic for several years or develop symptoms of heart failure. Echocardiogram shows varying degrees of right and/or left ventricular systolic dysfunction, along with left ventricular apical aneurysm, which is considered pathognomonic of Chagas cardiomyopathy. (Choice A) Blastomycosis is a systemic granulomatous infection usually involving the lungs that causes acute or chronic pneumonia. It can also involve extrapulmonary sites including skin (verrucous lesions, subcutaneous nodules), bone (osteomyelitis), and the genitourinary tract (prostatitis, epididymo-orchitis). (Choice B) Lyme carditis caused by disseminated Borrelia burgdorferi typically presents with atrioventricular conduction block. Cardiomyopathy is extremely rare and has not been reported in the United States. (Choice C) Dengue virus infection has degrees of clinical presentation ranging from a mild self-limiting febrile illness to dengue hemorrhagic fever with shock syndrome. Chronic cardiomyopathy is not seen with Dengue fever. (Choice D) Leishmania donovani causes visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar), which is characterized by insidious onset and progression of fever, malaise, weight loss, and splenomegaly. Educational objective: Chagas disease is the leading cause of dilated cardiomyopathy in Central and South America. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection and is characterized by myocarditis progressing to dilated cardiomyopathy, nonspecific electrocardiogram abnormalities including right bundle branch block and left anterior fascicular block, and development of left ventricular apical aneurysms.

stem: A 37-year-old man comes to the office due to generalized fatigue and weight loss over the last 6 months. He has no skin rashes, fevers, night sweats, cough, or diarrhea. He was diagnosed with HIV 6 years ago but does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal and BMI is 18 kg/m2 Physical examination shows small, mobile submandibular lymph nodes. Mucous membranes are moist with no lesions. The lungs are clear on auscultation. There is no organomegaly on abdominal examination. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL Platelets 69,000/mm3 HIV-1 ELISA positive HIV viral load 70,000/mL CD4 cell count 85/mm3 Toxoplasma IgG antibody positive Prophylaxis against which of the following pathogens should be initiated in this patient? (Toxoplasma gondii, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Mycobacterium avium complex, Cryptococcus neoformans)
explanation: This patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 85/mm3 and positive Toxoplasma serology. He should be initiated on antiretroviral therapy as well as prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii and Toxoplasma gondii. P jirovecii prophylaxis is recommended for patients with HIV who have CD4 counts <200/mm3 or evidence of thrush. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the preferred first-line agent; dapsone, atovaquone, or pentamidine are second-line options for those who cannot tolerate TMP-SMX. Testing for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is required prior to the initiation of dapsone. T gondii prophylaxis is required for patients who have CD4 counts <100/mm3 and positive IgG serology. TMP-SMX is the preferred agent but second-line therapies are available (as shown in the table). Mycobacterium avium complex prophylaxis with azithromycin (1,200 mg weekly) or clarithromycin is required for patients with CD4 counts <50/mm3. Cryptococcus primary prophylaxis is not recommended. The most effective way to prevent Cryptococcus is to initiate antiretroviral therapy. Histoplasma infection prophylaxis is sometimes considered for patients who live in endemic areas and have CD4 counts <150/mm3. Routine prophylaxis against other common opportunistic infections such as cytomegalovirus is not currently recommended. Educational objective: In patients with advanced HIV, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the preferred first-line treatment for prevention of pneumocystis (CD4 count <200/mm3) and toxoplasma (CD4 count <100/mm3 and positive IgG). Azithromycin is used for Mycobacterium avium complex prophylaxis when CD4 count is <50/mm3. Routine fungal prophylaxis is not generally required, but patients who live in Histoplasma-endemic regions often receive preventive treatment when CD4 counts are <150/mm3.

stem: A 38-year-old man comes to an urgent care center with sore throat and malaise for 3 days. He also has pain during swallowing. His past medical history is significant for mild intermittent asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and irritable bowel syndrome. His irritable bowel syndrome manifests as abdominal pain and diarrhea several times a year. He has had multiple male sexual partners over the last 10 years. He recently returned from a trip to Europe to visit friends. Examination shows pharyngeal erythema and shallow, tender ulcers on buccal mucosa. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Point-of-care testing for group A streptococcus is negative. Symptomatic therapy with acetaminophen and mouthwash is prescribed. The patient returns 2 days later due to persistent sore throat, fatigue, and new rash. He also reports poor appetite and 2 episodes of diarrhea. Physical examination shows a fine macular rash on his trunk, hands, and feet. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The patient has a persistent sore throat, new-onset rash, and diarrhea with a previously negative rapid strep test. He most likely has acute HIV. Acute HIV presents with "flu-like" symptoms, including fever, headache, fatigue, sore throat, nausea, diarrhea, and enlarged lymph nodes. Sore throat may be persistent and is often mistaken for other viral illnesses. The rash is macular with some papular features and typically appears on the trunk and face. The appearance of a rash signifies seroconversion, so HIV testing at this point is appropriate. (Choice A) Sore throat would be a very unusual extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease, making this diagnosis unlikely. (Choice B) Gonococcal pharyngitis usually presents in association with genitourinary symptoms but can also occur by itself. The rash associated with disseminated gonococcal infection is commonly associated with joint or tendon pain, is more peripheral (rather than truncal), and varies from maculopapular to pustular. This patient's lack of joint pain or genitourinary symptoms makes gonorrhea unlikely. (Choice D) Infectious mononucleosis typically presents in patients age <21 and can cause a sore throat with malaise and lymphadenopathy. Rash is seen in <5% of patients, but it is almost always (>70%) seen if the "cillin" antibiotics are given. (Choice E) Infectious diarrhea caused by toxin-mediated bacteria such as Escherichia coli can lead to complications such as hemolytic uremic syndrome. However, these patients do not typically have a sore throat and macular rash. Educational objective: HIV may present in its acute phase as a flu-like illness and as a cause of persistent sore throat. When a rash is present, HIV enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay testing is sensitive with a lower rate of false negatives.

stem: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department after coughing up blood-streaked, white sputum this morning, following a week of malaise and productive cough. Two months ago, he was evaluated for weight loss and oral thrush and was diagnosed with HIV infection. His initial CD4 count was 55/mm3, and HIV viral load was 1 million copies/mL. Interferon-gamma release assay testing was indeterminate at that time, and he was started on combination antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. The patient is adherent with his medication regimen. Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 16/min BMI is 17 kg/m2. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. No thrush is present and no enlarged lymph nodes are palpable. Coarse rhonchi are heard over the left upper lung field. There are no skin rashes or edema. Leukocyte count is 5,500/mm3, and chest x-ray reveals a dense consolidation in the left upper lobe. CD4 count is now 240/mm3. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Continue antiretrovirals and provide symptomatic therapy only
choice_b: Continue antiretrovirals and send sputum studies
explanation: This patient was recently diagnosed with HIV and started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). He now likely has immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) due to previously undiagnosed tuberculosis (TB). IRIS is characterized by paradoxical worsening of a preexisting chronic infection or unmasking of an unrecognized infection due to immune system recovery during the treatment of HIV. Patients usually develop IRIS within a few weeks or months of ART initiation. Most cases arise in patients with pretreatment CD4 counts of <100/mm3. Severity is usually greatest in those with high pretreatment HIV RNA levels who have a strong virologic (rapid decline in HIV RNA) and immunologic (rapid rise in CD4 count) response to therapy. Because IRIS is a diagnosis of exclusion, other conditions (eg, bacterial superinfection, drug allergy/toxicity, patient noncompliance) must be considered. Several opportunistic infections have been associated with IRIS, including: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Cryptococcus, Cytomegalovirus, Hepatitis B and C, Herpes simplex virus, Human herpes virus 8, John Cunningham polyomavirus, Pneumocystis. IRIS is typically self-limited and is primarily addressed by treating the underlying infection. ART can usually be continued without interruption, but patients who develop life-threatening complications (eg, airway obstruction due to an expanding inflammatory mass) often have to transiently stop ART (Choice C). Corticosteroids are generally not indicated but can be added for patients with severe or life-threatening symptoms (eg, obstructive mass lesions) (Choice D). (Choice A) The patient had an indeterminate interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) and now has manifestations (eg, cough, upper lobe infiltrate) of active TB infection; as a result, symptomatic care alone is inappropriate. He should undergo sputum testing for acid-fast bacilli and culture to establish a microbial diagnosis. (Choice E) Patients with HIV who have low CD4 counts are more likely to have indeterminate IGRA testing; therefore, IGRA is often repeated when CD4 counts improve. However, this patient now has symptoms and chest x-ray findings consistent with active TB; as a result, additional latent TB screening (with repeat IGRA) would not be indicated at this time. He should undergo sputum testing to establish a microbial diagnosis. Educational objective: Patients with HIV who have low CD4 counts (usually <100/mm3 and high pretreatment HIV RNA levels are at greatest risk for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, which is characterized by paradoxical worsening of a preexisting chronic infection or unmasking of an unrecognized infection within weeks or a few months of antiretroviral initiation. Treatment is generally focused on the underlying infection; antiretroviral therapy (ART) can usually be continued without interruption. However, patients with severe or life-threatening complications may require the temporary cessation of ART and/or the addition of corticosteroids.

stem: A 27-year-old man comes to the office to discuss HIV prevention. One of his sexual partners is an HIV- positive man who intermittently adheres to antiretroviral therapy, and the patient also has sexual encounters with men of unknown HIV status. The patient does not reliably use condoms due to loss of sensation during intercourse. He is concerned about his risk of HIV infection and is interested in the use of antiretroviral therapy or pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to prevent contracting the disease. The patient has had no recent fever, weight loss, rash, or malaise. He was diagnosed with gonococcal urethritis 3 months ago and was treated with antibiotics; he has no other medical history. The patient occasionally uses intranasal cocaine prior to intercourse and drinks a few beers on weekends. He does not use tobacco or injection drugs. The patient's vital signs are within normal parameters, and physical examination is significant only for diffuse tattoos over the upper extremities. Serum chemistry is normal, and viral hepatitis screening is positive for hepatitis C IgG antibody alone. HIV testing is negative. After careful discussion about safe sex practices, which of the following is the most appropriate next step regarding PrEP use in this patient?
choice_a: Advise against PrEP due to history of hepatitis C
choice_b: Advise against PrEP due to illicit drug use
choice_c: Advise against PrEP due to multiple sexual partners
explanation: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) can reduce the risk of HIV acquisition by >90% and is generally offered to those at substantial risk for new HIV infection due to: Sexual behaviors - HIV-positive partner with detectable viral load; men who have sex with men and individuals from high prevalence areas (eg, sub-Saharan Africa) with recent bacterial sexually transmitted infection, sex exchange for money, inconsistent condom use, or high number of partners; Injection drug use - HIV-positive injecting partner; sharing of injecting equipment. Treatment includes the use of once-daily 2-drug antiretroviral therapy with tenofovir plus emtricitabine. Two-drug therapy would incompletely treat active HIV infections, which can lead to drug resistance; therefore, to qualify for PrEP, patients must have negative fourth-generation HIV testing and no manifestations of acute HIV. Normal renal function and documented hepatitis B infection/vaccination status is also required. As hepatitis B can also be treated with tenofovir, patients with chronic hepatitis B infections can sometimes undergo combined hepatitis B and PrEP treatment. Patients on PrEP require follow-up every 3 months for HIV testing, risk-reduction counseling, and medication adherence/side-effect assessment. Regular creatinine levels and screening for bacterial sexually transmitted infections is also recommended. (Choice A) Direct-acting antiviral treatment for chronic hepatitis C does not usually interfere with the administration of PrEP. (Choices B and C) Multiple sexual partners and injection drug use are indications, not contraindications, for the use of PrEP. (Choice E) Three-drug antiretroviral therapy is required to treat an active HIV infection but is not used for PrEP. Educational objective: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with a once-daily 2-drug antiretroviral regimen (tenofovir plus emtricitabine) can reduce the risk of acquiring HIV by >90%. PrEP is generally offered to those at substantial risk of new HIV infection due to sexual behaviors (eg, HIV-positive partner, inconsistent/no condom use) or injection drug use. To qualify, patients must have negative fourth-generation HIV testing, no manifestations of acute HIV, normal renal function, and documented hepatitis B infection/vaccination status.

stem: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 1-week history of malaise and joint pains. She also has mild shortness of breath. The patient initially developed left elbow pain and swelling but now has pain in the right knee and ankle. She emigrated from Thailand 6 months ago and has resided with family members in New York City, none of whom have been ill. Her temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 104/64 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 20/min Lungs are clear bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals a blowing 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex. The right knee and left elbow are mildly swollen and tender. There are palpable subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surface of both arms. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 100 mm/hr and blood cultures are negative. Which of the following is most useful in confirming the diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's history (recent emigration) and presentation with fever, arthralgias, migratory arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, mitral regurgitation murmur, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Rheumatic fever occurs 2-4 weeks after pharyngeal infection with group A -hemolytic Streptococcus (GAS). ARF is a clinical diagnosis that is typically made using the Jones criteria (Table). Evaluation includes assessment of cardiac function and acute phase reactants (ESR and C-reactive protein) along with one of the following studies to establish GAS infection: Positive throat culture for GAS (negative in 75% of patients with ARF), Positive rapid streptococcal antigen test, Elevated or rising antistreptolysin O (ASO) antibody titer. Diagnosis of ARF is based on evidence of GAS infection and 2 major (or 1 major and 2 minor) manifestations of the Jones criteria. Patients must be treated with a full course of antibiotics to eradicate GAS carriage regardless of the presence of pharyngitis at the time of diagnosis. They are also at high risk for recurrence and progression of rheumatic heart disease with repeated episodes of GAS pharyngitis. Therefore, these patients must be treated with continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrent pharyngitis and limit progression of rheumatic heart disease. (Choice A) Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, also known as Wegener's granulomatosis), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), Churg- Strauss syndrome, and renal-limited vasculitis. Patients with GPA or MPA are typically older and have constitutional symptoms, leukocytoclastic angiitis, and pulmonary-renal complications. Cardiac valves are not typically involved. (Choices B and D) Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and rheumatoid factor are used to screen for systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and other rheumatologic autoimmune diseases. Patients may have constitutional and musculoskeletal symptoms as in this patient, but cardiac valves are not typically involved. (Choice E) Knee aspiration for synovial fluid analysis is indicated in patients with suspected septic arthritis or crystal induced synovitis. These conditions usually cause a severe monoarthritis, rather than the migratory polyarthritis seen in this patient. Educational objective: Acute rheumatic fever is characterized by fever, migratory arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, carditis/valvular heart disease, and elevated inflammatory markers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein). It is diagnosed clinically based on the Jones criteria in conjunction with confirmation of group A Streptococcal infection.

stem: A 68-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician due to fever and malaise. He developed abrupt-onset fever, headache, nonproductive cough, severe body aches, and generalized weakness about 24 hours ago. He has a 43-year history of smoking but quit 2 years ago. His medications include tiotropium daily and albuterol as needed. The patient has no other medical problems. He visited his grandchildren a week ago during Christmas and reports that his 6-year-old grandson was sick with similar symptoms. His temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. Pulmonary auscultation shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally but no focal crackles. Chest x-ray shows flat hemidiaphragms bilaterally but no focal infiltrate. A rapid influenza antigen test is negative. Laboratory results are as follows: Leukocytes 12,800/mm3 Differential: Neutrophils 80%, Eosinophils 3%, Lymphocytes 15%, Monocytes 2%. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment at this time?
explanation: In this patient with an influenza-like illness (fever plus cough and/or sore throat), the clinical suspicion for influenza is high (winter season, abrupt symptom onset, sick contact). In addition, the patient's age (265) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) place him at high risk of influenza complications (Table). Early antiviral therapy may decrease symptom duration, illness severity, and complication rates, particularly in high-risk patients and those with severe disease. Because this high-risk patient is within the first 48 hours of symptom onset, a neuraminidase inhibitor such as oseltamivir or zanamivir is recommended, rather than symptomatic therapy alone (Choice D). However, zanamivir should be avoided in patients with chronic pulmonary disease (eg, COPD, asthma) as it can precipitate bronchospasm and respiratory function decline (Choice E). Although diagnostic testing for influenza is recommended in immunocompromised or high-risk immunocompetent patients with influenza-like illness, treatment should not be delayed pending results availability. It also should not be stopped due to a negative rapid antigen test result in patients in whom suspicion for influenza is high (as in this patient) due to the test's low sensitivity (40%-60%) in diagnosing influenza. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) testing (more sensitive but less readily available) is preferred and should be performed for confirmation if available. (Choice A) Adamantanes (eg, amantadine, rimantadine) are effective against some influenza A viruses but are not currently recommended due to high drug resistance. (Choice C) Ribavirin is used to treat immunosuppressed patients with suspected lower respiratory tract infection from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV); it is not effective against influenza. Educational objective: Antiviral therapy is recommended for patients at high risk for influenza complications, particularly within the first 48 hours after symptom onset. In the absence of suspected resistance, oseltamivir is the treatment of choice for patients with suspected influenza infection with underlying pulmonary disease.
